reviewText:
Finished Shadowrun returns last Monday.

From my blog: http://www.dyle.org/blog/?p=233

Played fully on Linux with Steam (native, no Windows Emulation).

You play a character in the Shadowrun universe which is on the hunt to bring down a friend’s murderer. Time is around 2057 but due to the Awakening, the world is filled with science fiction high tech and fantasy elements alike. You have genetic modification, cyberplants and hacking warfare along with elves, orcs, dwarfes and trolls hurling magic bolts. A rich and fascinating universe.

… you have to work trough yourself. The game can be summed up by the phrase “too less”. At first there is too less background for the setting, the story. You just start off creating a character, like an orc, with cybernetic implants. Yep, no explanation to this. If you want to find out more about the Shadowrun world you have to look elsewhere but not the game.

Then there is too less RPG. Seldom you find something useful to pick up and equip. Also stats and skills are presented in a very sober way in a plain matrix. No introduction, no nothing. All at once, on page. Also you likely will spend points on attributes and skills you don’t need in future. Sorry, there is no turning back.

Then there is too less adventure. The story is nice, but you got not real decisions to make. The storyline is very linear. There are some side-quests, but guess: too less.

Then there is too less of a challenge. At the first two thirds of the game. I pimped my elf with quickness and assault rifles and the game was no real match at “normal” level. Strategic fighting is nice and … easy. Yeah, the games picks up some pace in the last third and starts to get harder. This is were the fun really sets in. But up to then it is playing a nice story …

And someone always has the idea of something missing. Something’s missing at the RPG, at the adventure, at the combat game, at the grafics, animations.

E.g. Harlequin is one of the coolest elves I’ve come along in playing games, but when he wields his sword he is animated as if someone had stiffed a broomstick right along his “back”. The in-game representation is missing the charisma and style this elf has in dialogues.

Finally the save game mechanics are just bonkers. Actually you just can save at the start of a level, better: the game (hopefully) autosaves at this stage. Making a wrong decision at the end of a level requires to replay to whole level again.

The pro: once you’ve delved into the universe the plot is great to play and the dialogs are really nice written, the combat is fun after all. It remains a nice game. Hopefully they fix this bad savegame mechanics and give more universe background information in the DLCs and patches to come.
Yeah i funded the kickstarter, im so cool ~ ^.^\nThis game is pretty fun, if you like very good story, better than actual gameplay

reviewText: It's a very fun game but I had no clue it was so story driven. For every 5 minutes of combat you have to read through 20 minutes of dialogue. This made the main story go by rather slowely for me but don't let that deter you because in the workshop you can find custom stories that have a much heavier focus on combat. Regardless it is still a great game and I would highly recommend it to anyone who likes turn based strategy games or anyone who likes to fully indulge themselves in a great story.

Its pretty good but really could have used some extra polish. Some skills are useless. Combat is turn-based and there are several spots in the game that won't end" a battle after everything is dead forcing you to travel in a turn based fashion when there are no living enemies left."

it's great fun, and has a slight replay value, depending on how much you like RPG's. It is great that they have slight nods to the\nSNES version and other versions of Shadowrun. The Combat is simple and fun, the game just works ^,^

Awesome game with a lot of classic Shadowrun references.  Very atmospheric, the main campaign is engaging but a little short.  After investigating every nook and cranny of the mostly linear map it took 20 hours to complete the campaign.

Awesome game.
The standout winner for me was the story, very well written.
Old school RPG, Cool elements, interesting characters, and turn based system once combat joins.
And you don't have to be a decker if you don't want to (Dragonfall made decking interesting however).

The Dragonfall DLC is outstanding (basically another campaign), and I would rate it better than the base game itself :D

Based on a great tabletop rpg game. Shadowrun manages to capture the essence and culture of the cyberpunk world. The story is interesting and the classes are faithful to the original. The game has simple graphics and easy to learn combat system (per turn). The narrative is direct, without many choices. The characters are mildly interesting. Worth picking up on a discount sale. 8/10

This is a really nice game that is similar to the old style of adventure games like Baldur's Gate and Fallout, the dialogue and narritive writing is detailed and very fun to read becausr the author spends time on describing intricate details of a scene and ties it together into a readable flow which you don't normally find nowadays in games for storytelling.

I'm only 5 hours in and I'm enjoying the writing as much as I do the gameplay itself, it is an RPG with turn-based combat, a feature which the game has taken from the old styled RPGs is the one where your custom designed character has a set of attribute points which are used for calculating results in combat as well as being useful when exploring or dialogue situations  (my character is good at hacking computers so I can open doors and access areas which would otherwise be inaccessible to me if I didn't have the correct skill points). Another thing this game is like is Mass Effect because it wants to combine the traditional fantasy RPG style of magic with a more modern/futuristic style of technology and and it does it pretty well.

The only downside to this game is that it isnt a fully voiced game and I sometimes get tired of reading a lot of text when I'm interviewing someone for information, only a small portion of the dialogue is voiced which would make the game more immersive for me.

It's absolutely stunning. I love pen&paper RPG, but I had never thought I'd love classical cRPG until I played this game. It's based on one of best RPG ever, with brilliant setting and good rules. Every piece is in computer game. You feel almost like on RPG session, which is amazing in cRPG.\nCampaign is short, but it's so moddable, that replayability is incredible.\nAnd for that money (I bought it on sale, it's on sale once again and will be lots of times probably)- it's like stealing. Seriously- less thinking, more buying!

The game features a good story and setting as well as fun oldschool gameplay with new twists.\n\nThe Dragonfall DLC is what makes it really memorable, though. It feels like the project team could fully concentrate on the content for it, and the result is an amazing and polished story with diversified runs.

This is one of the best RPGs I've ever played. If you like the SNES SR and you like Shadowrun in general this is probably going to eat some time up. It also has a DLC campaign that is WORTH the money. All in all running through the story mode linear took about 18 hours. The community content can keep you busy for 100s of hours.\n\n10 times better than most indie games that are getting a lot more cred and hype than this game. Shoot straight
recommended: and never make a deal with a dragon.""

reviewText: This is a great turn-based RPG. I truly enjoyed the setting, story, and atmosphere. The mechanics are simple and sound, but complex enough to be engaging throught the length of the game. The Dragonfall expansion improves on the game in every way and is well worth the price. Great game!

This is a linear rpg where you are led from point a to b with little opritunity to explore the world. In spite of this Shadowrun Returns is a fun game. The story is enjoyable, the combat satisfying, and chacter creation/leveling fairly deep. Another nice touch are the player mods wich allows you to keep running the shadows after the main story is finished.

I play the pen and paper RPG and this is a good really fun way to play when you dont have a group or an off time off waiting for you're next game with you're group it has a couple of cameo's mentions prominent Runners and the amount of things you can do and replay when you beat the Main Story and DLC and then play other people's Runs is worth the amount the game asks for 15$ well spent to me :) good luck fellow Runners.
I love this and dragonfall so much.  I hope they keep releasing things on this platform.  Also, the community has a LOT of great stories on there.\n\nReally love the game and hope to see more soon!

Bloody awesome RPG and a bloody awesome RPG. I don't regret spending a single cent on it. Basically it's a bit like a cross between Blade Runner and Lord of the Rings. You play a Shadowrunner, a bounty hunter who does difficult and risky jobs in a near-future world where magic has returned to the Earth, cyber-augmentation is very real, and meta-humans like elves and orks walk among us. Truly cool in every aspect, no?

Great game for fans of old school RPG at a great price. If you've read Neuromancer; and loved it, if you've spent countless hours playing Baldur's Gate or older Fallout titles; and couldn't tear yourself away from them, this is a game for you.

And once you're done with original campaign, quality user generated content awaits you on Steam Workshop and 3rd party sites like Shadowrun Nexus. Modders are so ambitious that they are recreating whole Shadowrun sourcebooks. So, come on, join us in the shadows, chummer.

Shadowrun Dragonfall: I know they are marketing this as merely DLC, but DLC this is not. It is a full blown, old fashioned expansion pack. Dragonfall packs a bigger campaign, set in the anarchy ridden Berlin of 2054, otherwise known as the Flux State.

HBS has listened to fans and addressed all the major issues from the original game. Saving your game anywhere? Check! More interesting companions with actual personalities and backstory? Yes, sir! Side missions? Of course! This time around you are not led by the hand. You get a hub, certain Berlin neighborhood, where you can choose your missions, even reject them if Mr. Johnson offering it isn't on the level. You can chat with the (meta)humans living there. Solve their problems. Learn of their past, and they all have some very shady skeletons in the closet. Let's face it, only people running from something come to the F-State...and corporations. But the latter are a different story altogether.

Runs themselves have been improved considerably. There are multiple solutions to every problem and some tough choices to be made in practically every one. Enemy encounters have been improved. Combat is more enjoyable, overall. Non-combat skills feature more prominently. Skills and etiquette checks are very frequent. You can go in guns, fists, blades and magic blazing. But you can also do things covertly. It's all up to you.

Writing in this game is great. Story takes hold of you, is full of twist and turns, and won't let you go 'till the end. By that time, you'll crave more. Speaking of length, you'll get at least twenty hours out of the game. Even more, if you play on harder difficulties, want to speak to everyone and see everything.

Dragonfall is the definitive reason to pick up the original game. If you're into old school RPGs, cyberpunk, and value a good story, you won't be disappointed with this game.

Great with just the core game, brilliant with the expansion. I am looking forward to working through some community mods next, if the storylines are any good this could be keeping me occupied for some time!

I recommend this only if it's on sale. Dragonfall I found more enjoyable than the base campaign, but it's still linear and short; given that user content comprises most of the gametime this release has to offer, I also only recommend it if it's on sale.

When you purchase this, you are purchasing a clumsy game engine with a short, linear example campaign. I only narrowly gave this thumbs up, because of the fact that most of the game's potential comes from user-generated content, which is made by people who will not not be seeing any of the money you pay. The engine itself is clumsy because it takes a lot of fiddling to make it immersive; doors cannot be closed again once open, by default; you have to set each one up to do so, etc. Places that look navigable are sometimes not. There is a lack of cover in places where there sems like there should be.

In short the product feels rushed, and most of the potential comes from people that are willing to work (for free)/adapt the tools released, rather than from the developers. Worth it if under 5$.

Bought the game on a whim during the Steam summer sale. It's a change from my usual games, but I was pleasantly surprised. The game is addictive with both an interesting storyline and characters that are sure to keep you hooked.

Absolutely loved this game. Though I must admit the combat was rather simple and seldom difficult the writing is great. How they weave the storyline with only text and even though your choices don't hold any weight on how the story will unfold it all seems so natural.\n\nRecommended for players looking for guided story telling. In truth the game is very linear but that's okay in my book. The combat isn't as good as XCom of which it seems so similiar. A little unpolished but again the whole graphical style. Love the cyberpunk cross mythical world theme. Looking forward to playing more.
This was a wholely entertaining game, while crazy amounts of user generated content to keep the fun going!
The writing really captures the essence of playing a tabletop shadowrun game.... The UI flow could use a little work, but i guess it gives it that 'indie' feeling...
The story, gameplay, and characters are just awesome. A great throwback to the original SNES version.

An excelent adaptation of the Shadowrun game.  Kicked me right in the nostalgia, reminding me of the old SNES Shadowrun game.  Controls can be a bit rough, but the story and character customization is great.  8/10
Aw damn this game is good. And Shadowrun is just an awesome setting...

Amazing game, sticks to the SR setting in the best way with an engaging storyline and decent turn based combat. My only complaint is that there isn't a bit more depth in your team dynamics in Dragonfall and that some members like Glory seem rather weak.

XCOM-esque combat, with a decent amount of customability (although some builds are a lot more viable than others.)   Not much RP capability compared to the board game, but understandable due to the format.
Not only are the two main campaigns really good. The crowd created adventures are fun as well.
great game!  reminds me of the SNES days.  a little to much reading, it would be nice to have voice acting instead of all the text to read
Great Game. Discout this week and worth every penny. Has the feel of the pen and paper board gam with out all the rules hunting.

I don't know if I'm playing this game correctly.  I REALLY WANT to like this game.  I've only played the story that comes with the game originally and as far as i can tell, there's no way to level your character before key fights.  It's very linear, and almost seams more like a vivid book than an actual game.  In the original Shadowrun, I would do tons of missions to get paid and level my items, then progress the story.  This version seems to lack the freedom that the original boasted.  Although I didn't have the fun that I wanted to, it is an extremely beautiful game.  It holds very true to the original lingo and settings as well.  There is a TON of user created content for this game, so I'm still going to give it a thumbs up.  Good luck, chummer!

You! Yes, you.  You like fantasy RPGs? You like strategy games? You like Sci-Fi? Ever wanted to mash 'em together into a delicous nerd smoothie?  Then do we have a product for you.

If you're an XCOM fan, the mechanics are pretty straightforward to you.  Honestly, Shadowrun Returns as simply a game is good, but not great.  The Karma system for leveling allows you to customize your character however you like with no limitations on class, though you'll want to specialize as you approach endgame.

However, Shadowrun Returns -- Shadowrun as a whole -- is so much more than a game.  It's a living, breathing world; a technologically heightened and magic-infused setting for stories of any kind.  Plots might hinge on the epic and esoteric (dangerous research into blood magic by a ruthless, profit-hungry megacorp) or the throwback noir with a twist (being hired by a dead man to find his murderer).  Sure, most of the RP of this RPG happens via old-school plain text, but you know what they call plain text in most places? Books. It ain't broke, so don't fix it!

Character creation remains fun to me, even after a few playthroughs.  It's pretty neat to tell your friends about your human shaman/street samurai who packs enough heat to take on a militia even before summoning his elemental spirits.  Or about your pink-haired elvish techno-wiz equally at home jacking into corporate Matrix blocks or rigging into her homemade combat drones with her very mind.  Moreover, the skills your character chooses will assist them outside of combat, unlocking alternate routes, hidden passages with loot, chances to solve a problem diplomatically (with added EXP!), and more.

The campaign that ships with the game, Dead Man's Switch, is a bit short but satisfying nonetheless.  It's an excellent introduction to the Shadowrun world, and veterans of the series will even see a few familiar faces.  Dragonfall, the DLC whose remastered version will drop tomorrow, is just plain phenomenal.  And that's not even touching the free Steamworks fan-made campaigns, some of which are truly brilliant.  Harebrained Schemes, the devs of Shadowrun Returns, have reminded us that a great game doesn't need 60 fps or 360-noscopes. You just need solid mechanics, a fascinating setting, and some hardcore writing chops.

Be sure to check out the pen-and-paper Shadowrun RPG, too!

Its a mix bag if you play the Snes(?) version of the first shadow run then this might fit your playstyle , i wish there was a option to go back to the first shadowrun battle style but the one in this version is 2nd best !

Okay I started playing at 8 pm and stopped at 3 am playing it without pause. Not because i wanted to, but because I am so tired right now. This game is in one word: awesome! If you played the pen and paper rpg you will recognize that the rulesystem is quite different to it. Its more dumbed down. But this is not bad. Actually its a question of gamedesign. And works quite good. This game lacks so many things. No voice acting no thrilling graphic style (all graphics are handdrawn). But this game has one thing i have missed in so many games the last couple of months. The just another mission effect. I couldn't stop playing.\nThe story is great. The writting is compelling (and there is a lot of text since there is no voice acting what so ever). It inherits the spirit of the first 2 Shadowrun rulesets. Version 1 and 2 maybe 3 with all its coolness and glory. If you ever liked the old Shadowrun, buy this masterpiece.

Shadowrun Returns original campaign:
This is a very nice Shadowrun based game, with a good story and gameplay. However, it is a short game and as soon as you learn how to optimize the character skills (and the enemies AI failures...) it is an easy game, even in the very hard mode. Also, it is an extremely linear game, not giving you any options besides the main track of the story. Still, it is a great game and I strongly recommend it to shadowrun lovers, such as myself.

Shadowrun Returns: Dragonfall:
This expansion package brings a very interesting and amusing story line. Definetively worth playing if you liked Shadowrun Returns original campaign. Note that it is not a continuation of the original campaing - you cannot bring your old character into this new campaign - altough some small references can be seem during the game. It is worth mentioning that this campaign is a little longer than Shadowrun Returns original campaign, but still a very linear game. Moreover, the dificulty level is
higher than in the original campaign.

Excellent game.  Great story and pretty sweet turn based combat.  Really felt like an old school RPG. The combat is not as intense as XCOM, but it's still fun and distributing stats to your character is great too.  Only thing is you are in charge of only one character and hire others to fill out your squad, which is okay but sometimes I wished I was able to assign stats to the characters on my team.  I did not encounter any bugs.  If it was a book it would be one of those I could not put it down" type books"
Awesome tactical combat and immersive atmosphere. A highly-customizable experience.
Old school goodness. if you like RTS, this is for you

This game, for a kickstarter, is shockingly polished and well written. I found it to be difficult but rewarding, not just for one playthrough but multiple playthroughs. When it's on sale, it's 100% worth it.
awesome ^^ finally a shadowrun video game that lives up to the name

Bought this after its release in 2013, and It was a pretty solid game
follows your run of the mill detective story with some nice combat thrown in

although while I havent played every class, each one has a unique feel to them which is awesome

A pretty good game and a blast from the past in terms of style. Its got an interesting world and characters. The main campaign feels very much like the one from Neverwinter Nights - a holdover until the community builds content via the editor.

The AI is a little weak; the game relies on overwhelming you with bad guys which is a bit annoying but overall combat is really interesting. It's sort of a cross between Advance Wars on the Gameboy and the freeware game Battle of Wesnoth.

Improvements for the future could be a party system that allows you to customise a team of 4. That would be a great addition.
Almost Arcanum, in cyberpunk world.

So Shadowrun Returns. A blast from the past. It's a fantasy/sci-fi turnbased role-playing game set in the shadowrun universe. It's similair to many of the other rpg classics. So what do you  get in the game? Character building, Many choices that don't impact the story but the gameplay, silent charcters (To roleplay better?), A catchy background music and lore that don't make sense if you are not well wersed. (Tho they are as a sidenote in the game and not relevent for the game itself) This is a kickstarted game based on nostalgia and i (Who did not kickstared it and havent even heard of shadowrun before) got hooked. Add to that it's expanding mod community this game is a most have for any lover of classic rpgs
Kvalitni cyberpunk RPG s izometrickym pohledem
Overall nice atmosphere, and great plot

To clarify, what this is not, is a sprawling open-world RPG with endless space to explore and fight and level up with the same character until you become and unstoppable behemoth that Blizzard is targeting premium content at on a daily basis. If you want that, look elsewhere.
Yes the graphics are a little retro, personally it works for me, it may not for everyone, if it doesn’t for you - since there are a huge number of videos and photos available to see before purchasing the game, I find whining about it a little childish, no?

What this is, is a fun and engaging storyline and an amazing opportunity for user generated content to provide a huge wealth of different experiences. To challenge yourself to find different solutions and to challenge yourself to myriad different play styles.
The user generated content will get there, and when it does, there will be so much to this game (that the studio could never have afforded to produce) that I foresee loosing many many hours blissfully jacked in.
If you doubt any of this look at the amount of user generated content for the dungeon crawler Legend of Gimrock, what you buy is a single campaign that takes a day or so to complete, what you get access to is a vast wealth of user generated dungeons created by people who, with the intricacy of their level design and fiendishness of their traps and puzzles, make the guy in the Saw films look like he really wasn't trying. If that can happen with this game (which I’m sure it will so long as the level creation and modding tools are there) it will be awesome.

If you like the pen & paper RPG or you're simply a fan of sci-fi turn-based combat you might want to try this. It has a sort of Fallout 2 feel to the gameplay though the story i very linear. Definitly worth the money and time in my opinion.
Short but fun.  Dwarf: mage shaman combo skills.  Unstoppable.  Fun just the same, with a good story.  No real replay value on its own.  But the steam community has provided some extra life.\n

Bom jogo com historia curta, previsivel mais interessante.
Nao tem mais de 10 horas de jogo o que faz vc nao explorar muito todas as skills.

Jogo e baseado em turno nas partes de luta
Love it

Excellent game, I buy at a Sale, and had no expectations, but the game mechanics are great, but no without a few flaws. For example the characters are low resolution, the game mechanics require a bit more of fine tweaks,
The main camping is good (linear, and some reports this is a issue however, I did not care about its linearity stills a good cyberpunk fiction) the game has great ambient from the look of the city's to the music it all gives that Blade Runner atmosphere.
And the game has tools and features for others to make their own scenarios and stories.
This game is better that I expected AAA level RPG.

One note this game is not voiced, is the ye olde king of read text, luckily for you, dialogs are not that long.

Refreshing single-player RPG experience. The game looks clean & sharp. There's not a lot of hand-holding (I finished the game without learning a LOT of the functionality - thankfully I went through on 'easy'), but that also means that there's no intrusive tutorial.  There could've been more, sure... but what is there is pretty darn solid and compelling. I finished in 2 sittings (first one lasting 8 hours). This game has a lot of potential for player-made content (my next stop is the workshop to see what is out there).\n\nOverall a very direct and clear-cut experience. Enjoyed it quite a bit.

If you took the writing from Dragon Age and Mass Effect and combined it with the gameplay from the Original Fallout and the X-Com remake and set it in the Shadowrun universe you would end up with this game. If any of those things interst you, I highly recomend this game. I have never read or played anything containing Shadowrun lore, but I felt right at home here.

Quite enjoyable for those of us who played the original Shadowrun and who like a good cyberpunk dystopia.  Gameplay is slow and reminiscent of early final fantasy although the enemies don't bounce when they attack but the story line is interesting, the graphics are very nice and it is an excellent break from FPS games where hair trigger is just a bit too slow.

Shadowrun is cyberpunk meets fantasy, all mashed together with the kitchen sink thrown in. Character classes include shamans (clerics), street samurai (fighters, melee or gun-based), mages, adepts (magical martial arts fighters), deckers (computer hackers) and riggers (who control drone robots). Player character races include humans, orcs, trolls (extra large orcs), elves and dwarves.

The world includes lots of fantasy monsters from spirits and giant scorpions to great dragons, and also plenty of security personnel itching to die at your hands.

Decking (computer hacking), and the way computers and the Internet work in general, doesn't make any sense at all. But this is totally consistent with the Cyberpunk genre, which was generally written by people with no real computer knowledge. Inside Cyberspace, you battle ICE (Intrusion Countermeasures) and even Black ICE (ICE that can kill you in real life).

I've played through the original plot of Shadowrun Returns (Deadman's Switch) and also Dragonfall. I thought that both games had really engaging stories, and were generally well-paced, had good dialogue and interesting characters. The scenes and themes fit well with a cyberpunk high tech

reviewText: It's a very fun game but I had no clue it was so story driven. For every 5 minutes of combat you have to read through 20 minutes of dialogue. This made the main story go by rather slowely for me but don't let that deter you because in the workshop you can find custom stories that have a much heavier focus on combat. Regardless it is still a great game and I would highly recommend it to anyone who likes turn based strategy games or anyone who likes to fully indulge themselves in a great story.

Its pretty good but really could have used some extra polish. Some skills are useless. Combat is turn-based and there are several spots in the game that won't end" a battle after everything is dead forcing you to travel in a turn based fashion when there are no living enemies left."

it's great fun, and has a slight replay value, depending on how much you like RPG's. It is great that they have slight nods to the\nSNES version and other versions of Shadowrun. The Combat is simple and fun, the game just works ^,^
This game is the closest you can come to experiencing God himself.
That moment you realize you have heard this sample before, oh yea, the same sample in Insanity is in Shadowrun Returns! You'll hear it.

I finally got around to playing this game. Picture the gameplay of XCOM: Enemies Unknown mixed with a book roleplaying game. AKA Shadowrun. I've roleplayed a lot, although never Shadowrun. But it feels like a nice little adventure. I'd say the game lasts about 12-15 hours. It gets a little slow paced though, it's very text heavy. If it was voice acted I think that would add a lot to it, but I don't fault it for that.

When you do get into combat, it plays almost exactly like XCOM. You get action points, 2 to begin with and you can either move or do an action like fight with those points during your turn. It's all turn based strategy on a grid. Overall I didn't find the combat to be very difficult, you hire a team before each mission to go with you but I played a Street Samurai and I was basically bread for combat.

That leads me to the character creation, I picked a Street Samurai as I mentioned, but you can pick from quite a variety of characters to begin with and tweak them as you play with Karma points. Like leveling up in the book RPG's. These various character choices lead to different dialogue choices and even options on the battlefield. So there is definitely variety and replayability here.

Speaking on replayability, this game also opens itself up to player stories and mods. You can download and create your own or others stories/adventures. So the game really has no end. It is certainly worth full price, but even better if you get it on sale. I would definitely recommend this game to any Cyberpunk style enthusiasts. If you liked XCOM you will like this combat system. Only gripe is all the reading. It makes me sleepy, but I pressed on and finished the main campaign and really enjoyed it.

One of the best turn based rpgs out there.  Rivals FF Tactics in terms of gameplay and story.  Found myself enjoying this game much more than I thought I would.  The writing is fantastic, but mind you there is a lot of reading.  If you dislike dialogue you may want try something else. I, for one, love a good story so the reading doesn't bother me.

I've never played the Shadowrun tabletop RPG, those aren't my bag. I did love the Shadowrun game on SNES that I played as a kid. This game brings a good blend of nostaglia for that previous title in a similar, but updated look, but it definitely also takes advantage of lessons learned in gaming in the intervening years. Combat in both the real world and while dekking is intuitive and easy to grasp. There are a number of skill tree options to monkey with, but not so many as to require a spreadsheet. Overall I found the game to be a satisfying experience, not terribly difficult, but that's not what I was looking for here anyway. Good times, definitely worth picking up if you enjoyed the old SNES game or the trailer to this one appeals to you.

So point and click, turn-based game play is usually an immediate no for me (I prefer fps tbh) but I was so intrigued by the plot I ended up buying this and I'm so glad I did. It's not voiced (something I didn't realise) but I don't think that hugely detracts from the game. I actually started to enjoy the combat! This is definitely worth a look at if you're as fed up as I am with major games and their ♥♥♥♥♥♥ 'plots'.
Shadowrun Returns = 7/10\nShadowrun Returns: Dragonfall = 8.5/10
classic rerun

This one campaign is included with the game and it is rather on the short side and linear BUT there are a few really good Workshop campaigns available for free and Dragonfall DLC, which I understand is much broader.

And there's also the editor, so you can make your own characters, maps, missions and campaigns if you want.

If you don't think being a half robot fighter than can take people's heads off with their fist is the raddest thing then please get out of my face."

Pros:
+ Solid storyline
+ Various builds that change how you play
+ Rewarding, challenging combat
+ Clever puzzles
+ Bug-free
+ The game ends on exactly the right note

Cons:
- Game is a bit short; campaign lasts roughly 20 hours if you do everything
- Relatively low replay value
- Straightforward campaign; for the most part, you stay on a single track through the main campaign, with only a couple chances for sidequests
- Charisma/Etiquettes*
- Specializing is required.  Jack of All Trades type characters don't do well.

Overall: Shadowrun Returns is fun.  You get to hire a crew and go do odd jobs as a mercenary in a futuristic dystopia.  The tone and music fits, the game gives you just enough money to get by and forces you to spend wisely, and the storyline is fast paced and fun.  The game is short, and there's not many chances for optional sidequests, but in spite of that the overall experience is still great.  If you're a fan of tactical isometric roleplaying games, this is a solid choice.

Bottom Line: A wild ride from start to finish, with fun characters, rewarding combat, and enjoyable gameplay.  A little short and straightforward, but well done in spite of this.  Worth the price.


* The charisma system in game works by giving you various etiquettes" which will open up conversation options if you know them.  Some etiquettes are extremely useful
date: others are entirely pointless.  Consult a guide when choosing which etiquettes to learn."

Pro:

Lots of community content

Lots of class/race options and tons of ways to build a character, and lots of spells/skills

Well-executed turn-based combat with a cover system akin to X-COM

Great story that pulls you into the world of Shadowrun (very text-heavy, enjoyable for those who like to read)


Con:

The RNG seems off sometimes (e.g. a 90% chance to hit might fail three times in a row)

The story is very linear, and there isn't a new-game+ option

Overview:

Pros:
-	2D environments and portraits
-	Interesting characters
-	great writing
-	refreshing setting
-	diverse skill system

Cons:
-	3D effects
-	linear story
-	story goes a little off the rail in the final act
-	endgame fights (enemies appear out of nowhere, required party members)

RPGs are my favorite genre. Nevertheless I didn’t enjoy recent RPGs like I used to. Yes, they might have great graphics, good gameplay mechanics or a well-crafted skill system, but the one aspect I find them lacking is the storytelling. Shadowrun Returns is an exception.
Before I start getting into the details, I have to say I watched several gameplay and review videos before I picked it up. To be honest – I wasn’t impressed. Even though the hand-crafted 2D environments are gorgeous and vivid, the character models as well as the visual effects are far from impressive. Nevertheless, I gave it a shot and I wasn’t disappointed.

The Shadowrun universe combines Cyberpunk aspects with the return of magic and metahumans in a futuristic world. The player slips into the role of a shadowrunner, an operative who will steal, infiltrate, hack and kidnap for the right price. The protagonist has to deal with powerful corporations, corruption, mythical creatures and fellow shadowrunners to survive.
When it comes to creating a character that is your own, Shadowrun excels. You can choose between five races you might find in a fantasy RPG (human, elf, dwarf, ork, troll), which feel quite fresh in this unfamiliar setting. Your character can choose from six pre-made classes:
-	Street Samurai: become a gun-wielding or close-range killing machine
-	Mage: Fireballs, buffs and Debuffs. The familiar choice.
-	Decker: jack into the Matrix to fight security systems with your programs
-	Rigger: use small drones to support your team or deal damage
-	Shaman: use totems or summon spirits to defeat your enemies
-	Adept: use magic to enhance your own abilities, making yourself a weapon

Furthermore you can also start from scratch and spend Karma points and create your own experience. Technoshaman? Combat Decker? Everything is possible, as long as you don’t spread the Karma points too thin. Skill checks are quite common in dialogue options and spending some points in Charisma or Intelligence can be worthwhile.
The inventory system is quite rudimentary. Characters wear an outfit and can carry up to three weapons. Everyone can carry up to six consumables and Magic users as well as Deckers have a spellbook with up to six slots. To further improve skills or stats, cyberware can be implanted. However this results in increased cooldowns for spells.
The gameplay revolves around a team of up to 4 shadowrunners. During the majority of the game you can hire a team and choose them depending on your group dynamics. Or your cash on hand, since shadowrunners don’t work for free. The combat system is round-based and reminds of Fallout 1 & 2. Action points have to be spend wisely to move, attack or use consumables like medkits and grenades.

You have to read! Where many games try to tell their stories with cutscenes and voice acting, Shadowrun Returns presents the story with superb writing. Whenever you travel to a new location or meet a character the situation is beautifully described before you have to worry about combat or dialogue choices. Combined with vibrant character portraits, the characters you encounter feel alive.

The different races and classes offer replayability. My first playthrough (normal, Human Decker) took 9+ hours. Due to the familiarity with enemy placement and linear storyline, my second run (very hard, Dwarf Mage) took a little over five hours. I can see myself coming back to try out different classes, however for now I’m enjoying the Dragonfall DLC (very hard, Troll Adept).

I would highly recommend this game to players who enjoy round-based RPGs, which concentrate on storytelling.

reviewText:
This is a fine piece of a turn-based RPG.
I defnitely enjoyed this great, albeit short,  game and would recommend it to anyone who enjoys turn-based rpgs, x-com enemy unknown/within, urban-science-fantasy settings and fantasy races.
A surprisingly good mixture of sci-fi stuff with near-like contemporary settings filled with elves, orcs, trolls and dwarves.

TL;DR - Great story/setting, great character customisation, levels/gameplay is fairly linear which restricts the RPG elements of the game, overall a really fun game, worth the money, just have to take it as it is.

Before I give my thoughts on this game, I'd like to make it clear that this is the first Shadowrun game I have played, although I am aware of the franchise and it's history. (Tabletop, PC/Console games etc.)

Story/Setting: The game overall is pretty solid and good fun. It has a decent story with twists and turns and an amusing ending. You encounter likeable characters and the world is a great representation of Cyberpunk, with it's own take on things with the addition of magic.

Character Customisation:You get to make your own runner at the start of the game and there is a lot to work with from melee characters, armed characters, Deckers (hackers), Riggers (drones), Mages (spells, traps, heal), Shamans (Similar to mages, can also raise spirits, creatures and demons). However where this game shines is you really have the power to go all out with one type of class or mix any of them and make a unique build of your own. (I think I got all the classes correct there. Or near enough!)

I'd say this game has great potential for replay value as you could try out all the different classes avaliable, however it wouldn't be something you'd jump straight back into after compleing in my opion, as the story and levels are fairly linear.

Mechanics/Gameplay:Everything works as it should in this game and I encountered no issues at all. However I would say the game is a little lacking in RPG elements in my opinion. Let's call it CRPG-Lite! (That was terrible)

A couple of areas that came to mind;

In conversations you do have the ability to convice, bribe and use etiquettes to persuade and win people over to your side which you would expect with an RPG, but, what I feel was lacking was that you can't really ♥♥♥♥ someone off in dialogue or make them hate you and never talk to you again like you can in some RPGs, ultimately conversations (It would appear) all have the same conclusion, you just have little things you can do here and there if you spec'd in charisma, you bribe them or have the correct etiquette.

I think this is because the levels and story are fairly linear for an RPG that it can't really give you that freedom. There are oppourtunities that you can miss out on if you give the wrong responses, but in an RPG I want it to be truly diverse in the sense that I can ♥♥♥♥ up an oppurtunity and then I have to go out of my way find another way to achieve my goal/quest. This game ultimately always seems to come to the same conclusion regardless.

The other major area that felt a little lacking was the combat, it has the average top down, turn based combat mechanics but I wish it was more like Wasteland 2's. You can get behind cover, but some you can't shoot around, your character literally can't step out with one foot and shoot around a doorway or down a corridor. Just a bit more control over combat and the ability to make better stratergies would have made the combat near-perfect!

Other little issues I had were things like not being able to examine the environments other than what the devs wanted you to see. Lack of dialogue/text box like in most RPGs, that displays examine text, Character thoughts and NPC dialogue etc.

Overall:Overall this is a really fun game, I played it through in a few days and was pretty glued to it. At first I was a little disappointed with the lack of RPG elements I'm used to, but I quickly accepted that Shadowrun is it's own thing and does it a little differently.

I'm really impressed with Harebrained Schemes and that they've successfully brought back Shadowrun. Now I have Dragonfall and Hong Kong to play, and from what I hear they've been improved a lot from this game!

An RPG that takes place in the Shadowrun setting, which is a mixture of Fantasy and Cyberpunk. Humans, dwarves, elves and other metahuman races walk the planet, while corporations rule the world. The setting is definitely solid, and has a lot of background knowledge, that makes for a rich world.

Gameplay consists of navigating your characters across an isometric map, interacting with people and objects, and fighting. Combat is turn-based and relies very much on cover, although there are playstyles that do not.

Character is freeform, but starts with a certain archetype, which you can then customize as you gain Karma, the resource used to develop your character.

The story is good, but the greatest charm of the game has got to be writing, and the various side quests and dialogues, that make up the universe. However, none of it voice-acted, so if you do not like reading, don't buy the game.

All in all, its definitely worth the price as intro to the series, but I will not be held responsible if you get addicted.

Bottom line: If you like turn based combat and this game is on sale for 5-10$, go for it.

Fun Factor: 70-73/100

Game Time:  Around 30-45 hours.  I left the game on a few different nights, so chalk up 16-30 hours of Steam's recorded play time" being from that.

A great tactical rpg.

I really enjoyed the game. Shadowrun has a very interesting world and good dialog. The combat system is okay, fairly standard for a turn based tactical game. Downsides were few: selecting things in combat can be clunky, leading to mis-clicks and an inability to move some characters where you want them: the game overall was quite easy as well. I didn't have a single character die, or even get close to death in the campaign and I don't think this is because I played particularly well. Money was very readily available, to the point where I could buy anything I wanted. Overall a good game, mainly for the story, novel setting and dialog.

The first new PC game I've actually felt compelled to complete in ages.\n\nAn interesting story, solid gameplay mechanics, and an acceptable difficulty curve. I felt compelled to keep playing, which is unheard of for me with RPGs these days, and truly stands out as special. I went and bought the next Shadowrun game immediately after.

Dead Man's SwitchShadowrun Returns. Indeed it has... this intriguing isometric RPG is a great combat system wrapped in a rollicking mystery that although has a few stumbling points, it is very much worth your time. Returns comes with a built-in campaign that will last you 10-12 hours if you take your time, and with plenty of mods in the community to keep it fresh.

Gameplay
Shadowrun Returns has a basic isometric movement system, just click where you want to go/interact with. It's when you get into the easy-to-learn combat system that the game really opens up. You can create your Runner to be a Sorcerer, a Drone-using mastermind, or just a guy with a shotgun that shoots people in the face. The RPG system is good, not overly complicated, and has good conversation trees that can be affected with different levels of Charisma. You can even role-play what type of things your character is knowledgable in. Overall, the gameplay of Shadowrun Returns is slick and stellar.

Story
Shadowrun Returns has a story that doesn't quite work on the empathy stakes... there's no reason really to care for any of the characters you meet, and some of the Runners you can hire are simply generic. If they die, it's just a *shrug* and leave them behind. However, the actual mystery behind the game and what's going on I found to be motivating enough... although it starts off slow, you want to meet the 'Ripper' until you actually stop playing the game- though after you've met him, things really start to get interesting...

Graphics, Atmosphere, and Sound
The graphics of Shadowrun are servicable; sure, they won't dazzle you, but they aren't bad either. It has a nice art-style to make the world come to life, and the character portraits help give you first impressions of the characters, as well as the information that comes through text-wise.
The atmosphere is great, with dank hotels and rain-drenched streets beckoning your Runner on. The characters are as fleshed out as you can get in a 'short' campaign as the Dead Man's Switch, but personally, I won't miss any of them.
The music quality in this game is impeccable. If you are a fan of electronic music, you won't regret listening to the tracks that are on offer here. 'Double Cross' is my personal favorite track. The additional sounds of guns and sorcery that permeate the air whilst fighting adds to the atmosphere.

Conclusion
Shadowrun Returns, A Dead Man's Switch, is a joy to play, and although the story has a few hiccups and the companion system leaves a lot to be desired, the game is overall a solid reccomendation. Worth your time indeed. Ready to deck into the system?

Good game, plays nice, reminicent of Fallout. Some annoying things here and there, like no manual saves and there's not real weight to some of the choices you make in the game. But it's simple, easy to pick up and play, and the main story is nicely done.\n\nBut what's rad is the potential, with the mod tools, to give the community great power to make something amazing. I'll also try to make something for it too. :D

The Good
For me the biggest best part about this game is that it's Shadowrun, and I love Shadowrun.  And I mean this is actual, proper SR too, not like some of the dribble that's carried the SR name in the past.  It's made by some of the folks who created SR in the first place, and it definitely shows by how deeply entwined with the actual lore it is.  If you like - or, like me, love - SR, you owe it to yourself to get this game.

But that's not all!  The writing is top notch, with great characters and a great story with lots of neat twists and turns.  The art is beautiful, making the game look like a painting come to life.  And the turn-based tactical combat - while not exactly original - is very well-executed and fun to play.

Further, it's set up so you can make your own campaigns, which is pretty dang cool in my book.

The Bad
Though I understood pretty much everything that was going on in the story, understanding almost every reference and technical term that came flying my way, I'm not entirely certain it would be nearly as accessible for anyone who doesn't already know the SR rulebooks forwards and backwards or is at least somewhat familiar with the setting.  This may be a foundless fear, but I figure I should mention it just in case.

Character stats were greatly simplified from the original systems, and even compared to at least one of the previous SR video games, which I do understand to a degree.  But I feel they may have simplified a little bit too much, and would have welcomed a little more depth.  That may be just me being a rules lawyer, tho'.

Overall
If my comments above don't speak plainly enough for themselves, I don't really have much bad to say about this game, but I fully realize that that might simply be my own pro-Shadowrun bias.  The game does have its faults, and I do wish it had a bit more depth than it does, but overall I feel that its pros far outweigh its cons, so I feel very confident in recommending it to folks.  And if you can, play the SNES and Genesis games first!

Pros:

Final Rating 9.5/10

Did you like fantasy games with elfs, orcs, trolls and magic? Now put it in a dark cyberpunk world with guns, tecnology, hacking. That is Shadowrun Returns.

It was based from the tabletop game Shadowrun, and it is amazing. If you like playing tabletop RPG games, you must read the books.

Gorgeous old school game! It has that ineffable spirit. It carries away! I want to quickly find out what the end of story! Game is played in one breath. And though the ending leaves a dual impression, after beating the game I had the feeling of reading fantastic novel. Thank you.

Shadowrun returns was a kickstarter project that gained traction rather fast, although like most kickstarters this was due to nostalgia. This game stands on its own extremely well.

Shadowrun returns is a cyberpunk fantasy tactical rpg, which in retrospective sounds absurd but its an idea that works really well and is amplified by the impressive dungeons and dragons art style.

Typical for an RPG you level up with points gained from battles but what you put your points into in this case either help you or hinder you.

Upgrades are apart of the experience and have a tradeoff mechanic, sacrificing one thing to gain something else, but comes into play later in the game.

During my time with the game the battles were more interesting than the story and in an rpg story should be just as important as the rest of the game.

The game stands on its own legs and is a good experience for someone who enjoys strategic rpg games and/or cyberpunk settings

Rating: 8.5/10

While I like this game a lot, others may not, depending on what they're expecting.

If you are expecting any edition of the tabletop role-playing game, or the Genesis or SNES console games, you will be disappointed.  Shadowrun: Returns plays something like a simplified version of tabletop rules that never actually existed.

I liked the plot, combat, and music.

Opinions on the plot vary widely.  If you have an aversion to reading, this game is not for you.  Almost all of the plot is delivered via screens of text upon entering an area, or text dialogs.  There is no voiceover.  Some people complain of purple prose, or that it seems to have been written by someone that is immature, but the writing is superior to that in most video games, including most other RPGs.  I personally do not perceive any of these problems, and have never seen examples cited.

Screenshots do not do the combat system justice.  Some of the interface is only displayed when it is relevant.  For example, the action point cost of movement, and the effectiveness of cover, only appear when you prepare to move, and when cover exists in the area you mouseover.  The combat system is relatively simple (which is reflected in the user interface), but like Chess, can be quite difficult.  The difficulty is selectable at character creation, so if you find the game too easy or hard you can adjust it.  Since almost all RPGs are combat-heavy, it's important that it not be mindless and repetitive.

The music is hard to describe.  It is not ambient.  You will notice it.  I especially like the theme on the title screen.

I didn't like some things about Shadowrun: Returns.

It is very linear, and most decisions will not affect the ending.

The gameplay in the matrix is very similar to meatspace.  It's not so much that the gameplay in the matrix is bad as it doesn't feel different enough.

The game only saves on area transition.  If you have to stop playing, or die, unexpectedly, you can lose quite a bit of progress.
Got to be the elvish JC Denton.\n10 I'm not big into books" out of 10!"

Well, I have to say I'm glad to be able to change my thumbs-down review of Shadowrun Returns to thumbs up. The fix for save files has been working fine for me with some flaws, but you will decide for yourself if this suits you fine or you might get DRM-free version that appearantly doesn't have these problems... I've used several different solutions and my own experiments to come up with the fix that works.

So, this is my story with Shadowrun.

I saw a few promotional posters here and there. Nothing more. Then one day, a good buddy of mine gifts me Shadowrun Returns and Shadowun Dragonfall. I didn't touch any of these in a long time because my reviewing and gaming queue was really choke full.

But one fateful night I decide to check out the playing order of Shadowrun games and I install this one. After creating my character, I've found myself in my smelly apartment wiith a dead friend asking for help. And I immediately fall in love. TOTALLY.

Shadowrun universe is one of the best I've encountered in a long time. This clash of tech and fantasy was something I even dreamt of writing about myself (until I've realized it's been done before and better). When I've figured out there are BOOKS out there about Shadowrun world... I nearly ♥♥♥♥♥♥ my pants and figured out I'll die happy. You will be entering the strange cyberpunk retrofuturistic world filled with noir style crime mysteries, corporate thrillers and technology ruling the flesh.

The storyline and game itself is fairly linear, but it made me care more about roleplaying - there's never a dull moment and nobody asks you to milk the cow (read: nonsensical sidequests) when you're in the middle of exciting main mission. That way you truly feel like you're doing something important.

Battle system is similar to that one seen in XCom games (turn based combat), and RPG system is decent and effective, making you care how you distribute your Karma points.

The only true problem I had with Shadowrun Returns on Steam is the fact that at certain point I've started having major problems with save files - to cut the story short, game stops recognizing your saves. By doing this, you will be able to play the game, but Steam time tracking will not work. If you're into tracking your time (as much as I am), you can always run a Steam edition of the game beside second one.

I am playing on Windows 7 64bit. I am not responsible for any accidents or nuclear meltdowns caused by copying and pasting. BACK EVERYTHING UP.

If you all of a sudden get greyed out CONTINUE button and you are not able to load your game, try this.

1. Go to C:\Users\YOURUSERNAME\AppData\Local\Harebrained Schemes\Shadowrun Returns\Saves and copy all the files. These are your save files. COPY THEM.
2. Go to your Steam folder. There, find the following folders \userdata\YOURPERSONALNR\234650 . Inside 234650 folder you will see two folders, one named Local, the other named remote. Back those up, just in case. You're bound to find some save files in these folders, but sometimes it's not the case. Now, paste AppData/Local... save files to both of these folders. If system asks you to overwrite, overwrite.
3. Now, most people say you need to restart Steam and start it in admin mode. This may help you once, just as it helped me, but then you'll encounter greyed out buttons again. The way I made my saves work is that I ran my game directly by clicking Shadowrun.exe from \Steam\steamapps\common\Shadowrun Returns.

Pros: your save games work.
Cons: no Steam overlay, no time tracking.

I would usually not lose this much time to figure things out, but Shadowrun is SO GOOD and when I heard Dragonfall and Hong Kong are even better... oh, happy times!!!

Less than I hoped for.

Shadowrun feels half-baked in a couple of ways:
1) The writing was made with care, but there are far too many allussions and jargon phrases that are used without explanation. It feels like jumping into a conversation after its started
2) The games menus and iventory don't seem to be finished or have all the detail other games might.
3) The game is short. Like really really short. For an RPG, that's usually dissapointing.
4) There's all kinds of class/skill options, but there usefulness seems questionable.
But there's a silver lining!

Combat system has potential, there could be great mods.
Puzzles were clever and challenging.
The universe is fascinating.
Art style is beautiful.

If you liked the Sega Shadowrun game, this will bring back a lot of memories. Love it. The new patch and DLC addresses the save anywhere issue. It's a great representation of the old pen and paper RPG on your PC.

For years now I've considered old-school isometric genres to be 'my' genre. That is to say, the one that strictly caters to my sensibilities as a player. I discovered them well after their golden age, and since this wave of kickstarted CRPGs began I've been eagerly awaiting their results.

As the first one out of the gate from this batch, Shadowrun Returns does not disappoint. If you're like me and you've been aching for a deep and immersive roleplaying experience and actual agency when it comes to solving problems, this game is a steal at $20. Excellent writing, beautiful environments, and a fantastic soundtrack all tied together with engaging combat and character progression.

The campaign will take you about 15 hours to run through, and there's sadly little in the way of extended diversions, and the game is rather linear in how it progresses. There's not much of a sense of an 'open world' that one would expect from this genre, but even still the world itself is one of the most well-realized and vibrant ones I've seen in a long time.

They've got another campaign on the way, and you're going to see plenty of gameplay content coming out of the steam workshop, so I can guarantee you'll have your money's worth in actual meaty game.

If you like RPGs at all you owe it to yourself to grab this game and play through it. You'll be really glad you did.

One of the rare games i was actually able to sit down and spend 3 to 4 hour sessions on. Kept me thoroughly entertained for all the 12-13 hours it took me to complete it.

The environments has a lot of detail and atmosphere, and the soundtrack compliments it very well. I really enjoyed the at times cheesy Sci-Fi story as well, nice set of characters, each with their own personality. And depending on what character you play as they will interact with you differently.

There is a lot of game here for the small price, even more so when you factor in Steam Workshop. A guy is even remaking the old SNES game, using Returns game editor, which is just amazing.

If your into Sci-Fi, RPG´s and turn based combat, you should really give it a go.

Bloody awesome RPG and a bloody awesome RPG. I don't regret spending a single cent on it. Basically it's a bit like a cross between Blade Runner and Lord of the Rings. You play a Shadowrunner, a bounty hunter who does difficult and risky jobs in a near-future world where magic has returned to the Earth, cyber-augmentation is very real, and meta-humans like elves and orks walk among us. Truly cool in every aspect, no?

Great game for fans of old school RPG at a great price. If you've read Neuromancer; and loved it, if you've spent countless hours playing Baldur's Gate or older Fallout titles; and couldn't tear yourself away from them, this is a game for you.

And once you're done with original campaign, quality user generated content awaits you on Steam Workshop and 3rd party sites like Shadowrun Nexus. Modders are so ambitious that they are recreating whole Shadowrun sourcebooks. So, come on, join us in the shadows, chummer.

Shadowrun Dragonfall: I know they are marketing this as merely DLC, but DLC this is not. It is a full blown, old fashioned expansion pack. Dragonfall packs a bigger campaign, set in the anarchy ridden Berlin of 2054, otherwise known as the Flux State.

HBS has listened to fans and addressed all the major issues from the original game. Saving your game anywhere? Check! More interesting companions with actual personalities and backstory? Yes, sir! Side missions? Of course! This time around you are not led by the hand. You get a hub, certain Berlin neighborhood, where you can choose your missions, even reject them if Mr. Johnson offering it isn't on the level. You can chat with the (meta)humans living there. Solve their problems. Learn of their past, and they all have some very shady skeletons in the closet. Let's face it, only people running from something come to the F-State...and corporations. But the latter are a different story altogether.

Runs themselves have been improved considerably. There are multiple solutions to every problem and some tough choices to be made in practically every one. Enemy encounters have been improved. Combat is more enjoyable, overall. Non-combat skills feature more prominently. Skills and etiquette checks are very frequent. You can go in guns, fists, blades and magic blazing. But you can also do things covertly. It's all up to you.

Writing in this game is great. Story takes hold of you, is full of twist and turns, and won't let you go 'till the end. By that time, you'll crave more. Speaking of length, you'll get at least twenty hours out of the game. Even more, if you play on harder difficulties, want to speak to everyone and see everything.

Dragonfall is the definitive reason to pick up the original game. If you're into old school RPGs, cyberpunk, and value a good story, you won't be disappointed with this game.

Shadowrun Returns is a turn-based cyberpunk RPG, similar to dungeons and dragons, with a digital dystopian twist. This game is an adaptation of the original table top game and reflects this in the flexibility of character choices and play styles, despite having a fairly limited and linear story line. The overall artistic style is gritty and cyberpunk; reflected in the graphics, music and dialogue. The combat system is tactical and challenging. The narrative is somewhat impractical but mysterious and compelling throughout the story. An awesome game from an independent developer on a small budget, worth a look for any role playing fan.

reviewText: BUY IT

Shadowrun Returns lives somewhere between a point-and-click adventure and a tactical RPG like XCOM: Enemy Unknown, but the lack of voice acting and completely linear plotline makes everything seem unfinished. However, once you accept the forced march through story, it's actually pretty well-written and the combat is fun. Just expect everything to be a dime short of a dollar--this game has all the hallmarks of a project that ran out of money too soon. However, since this game is modular and easily modded (http://www.nexusmods.com/shadowrunreturns), it may improve over time.

The first story module that comes with the game, Dead Man's Switch, is not quite as interesting as the first DLC module: Dragonfall.

TL;DR: If you enjoy turn-based, three-quarter RPGs such as Fallout 2 and Baldur's Gate 2, you may enjoy this one, especially if it's in the $5-10 range.
Really fun game cant wait till they release the seperate online version to play with friends, makes me want to play the table top again

very reminencent of neverwinter nights or similar rpg games, but not nearly as confusing. Shadowrun has really easy to understand mechanics that do not alienate players new to the system. the setting is wonderfully cheesy and awful. the story it comes with is pretty short with a lot of spelling and gramatical errors in the dialogue, but otherwise is a pretty solid experience.

Shadowrun Returns really embodies what Shadowrun is all about (unlike that horrific multiplayer debacle that was released not so long ago, ack!). The responses for your character in dialogue are varied enough to make it feel like you can actually roleplay a little (which is what a real RPG is, a game you can roleplay). It flows nicely and really makes me think back to all those Pen and Paper sessions.

I honestly didn't experience much in the way of bugs. And now that saving anywhere has been added it is pretty close to Shadowrun Perfection.

I've only had a chance to play Dead Man's Switch so far and I found the story and characters interesting and engaging. And it was pretty cool to see some recognizable faces from the books in the game.

Combat seems to flow pretty smoothly. I played a decker, they're my favorite archetype in P&P so I had to. I was pleased with the amount of time I got to spend in the Matrix and the way it was integrated into the gameplay so that it didn't detract from the game for the folks in the real world. I also noticed a lot of opportunities for people who prefer the other archetypes  to shine and I like the way the game noticed little things like my character's gender and race.

All in all I would most definately recommend this game. It really IS Shadowrun and I love it. Great job guys!! If you are a fan of Shadowrun or cyberpunk then you should definately check this out.
Purrfect game for me

I played the Sega game Shadowrun......... yes I am old.  This is a great story, and the free content is a BONUS! The DLC is a must.  For those who Play the 5th edition pen and paper version IT IS NOT THE SAME! I love the game and will continue to play it.  Keep up the good work.  It is hard to out do your first story these dooods did it with the DLC. Looking forward to the next DLC. Mabey mix in some Teconomancer.  I hope this game will inject some new blood to the 5th edition pen and paper version.

Strangely satisfying to play Shadowrun again. Easy to play and a nice plot (but not very surprising unfortunately). Lots of good DLC available, some of it better than the original... :-)\n\nIf it's not possible to play the P&P version of Shadowrun, than this is a good replacement. Until you find a group of real players of course.

Shadowrun Returns is a game I find hard to give excessive praise, but it's a game that I also find hard to dislike. When it comes down to it, it's a completely solid game, even if it's shallow. Nevertheless, I enjoyed it and feel fully satisfied with the experience, and I didn't have any trouble playing all the way through. There are certainly some notable flaws, however.

Let's start with the story, since this game relies heavily on it's writing to motivate the player. The writing and characterization is good, I felt very absorbed in the universe, but the story itself is fairly lacking. It's a shame as well, it starts out great. You got a murder mystery with a lot of interesting faces dying to be talked to, with a few twists and turns here and there. The problem is that it just doesn't developed. It feels extremely rushed. The characters are lovable and relatable to the very end, but I started skipping through dialogue that dealt with the actual plot about 2/3rds through the game. It escalates in a comical direction, with an extremely weak and one-dimensional villian. It's extremely predictable, and just plain boring. The last stretch is so typical and lackluster that I had little to no investment in the actual plight, I just wanted to see if the characters would drop some more interesting backstory about themselves. It gave me closure, but it's not memorable at all. It's just too bad, the beginning was really good, but the plot started going so fast in such a linear direction that it forgot to flesh itself out, leaving some questions unanswered and plot points underdeveloped. It got the job done, but I was hoping for more.

Where the game really shines are the characters and their own personal issues. Almost all the staple characters have their own personal motives and vendettas, and I was interested in all their stories. I enjoyed going back to base and talking to every single one of them that were willing to open their mouths. The game does a fantastic job of setting up this belonging feeling, that you're part of this organization of runners. Although, as I stated before, as the game escalates it leaves behind this deep characterization in order to fawn over its own hilariously absurd and out-of-place world-threatening dilemma.

The combat is serviceable. It's ultimately shallow and linear, there isn't a lot of variation or depth, and there are some balance issues. But it's still fun, you get to characterize some characters simply by their fighting styles. It's too easy as well, but not game-ruiningly so. It's fun, if you really like X-COM-like turn based combat, you'll probably enjoy it if you can stand it being a tad shallow.

The game is overall fun, I would recommend it. It doesn't really have any offending flaws, it just doesn't quite reach the large potential it could've. It's not particularly memorable, but it's enjoyable. I would wait for a sale, but when the price is suitable to you, I'd say to go for it just to get immersed in the world.

Funded this game back when the kickstarter campaign was around. Spent $10, and would gladly spend $20+ on it. Granted, I am a long-time shadowrun fan, but it's a great game for rpg fans.

While the graphics may not be the greatest, and the original story was pretty good at best (the Dragonfall DLC definitely makes up for it, it's another game in itself), what really makes up for it is all the user generated content that is coming out.

A reboot of the snes title was the first project I saw pop up, and have been following since.
Shadowrun Unlimited, is more of a non-linear style of game. I'm only a couple of hours into it, but there is so much more to it than the original game (more cyberware, more programs to be used in cyberspace, etc.), and it has much more replayability (random missions) than the original game.
That's just a couple of mods that I've been keeping an eye on, and there's plenty more where those came from.
If you like turn-based strategy, with both mystical (magic, dwarves, elves, etc.) and futuristic elements, it's most definitely worth picking up.
This game is a lot of fun. Awesome storyline and tactical combat. Easy to play, hard to master.

Like RPG? Enjoy storyline and contents over next-gen graphics?

Dragonfall is all about authentic atmosphere. The sharp and to the point writing is pure artistry. Playing this game was quality time for me. In many ways, I think this was better than the previous title.

As a Shadowrun fan, this is defiantly one of the best games I have ever played.
This game is the closest you can come to experiencing God himself.
That moment you realize you have heard this sample before, oh yea, the same sample in Insanity is in Shadowrun Returns! You'll hear it.

I finally got around to playing this game. Picture the gameplay of XCOM: Enemies Unknown mixed with a book roleplaying game. AKA Shadowrun. I've roleplayed a lot, although never Shadowrun. But it feels like a nice little adventure. I'd say the game lasts about 12-15 hours. It gets a little slow paced though, it's very text heavy. If it was voice acted I think that would add a lot to it, but I don't fault it for that.

When you do get into combat, it plays almost exactly like XCOM. You get action points, 2 to begin with and you can either move or do an action like fight with those points during your turn. It's all turn based strategy on a grid. Overall I didn't find the combat to be very difficult, you hire a team before each mission to go with you but I played a Street Samurai and I was basically bread for combat.

That leads me to the character creation, I picked a Street Samurai as I mentioned, but you can pick from quite a variety of characters to begin with and tweak them as you play with Karma points. Like leveling up in the book RPG's. These various character choices lead to different dialogue choices and even options on the battlefield. So there is definitely variety and replayability here.

Speaking on replayability, this game also opens itself up to player stories and mods. You can download and create your own or others stories/adventures. So the game really has no end. It is certainly worth full price, but even better if you get it on sale. I would definitely recommend this game to any Cyberpunk style enthusiasts. If you liked XCOM you will like this combat system. Only gripe is all the reading. It makes me sleepy, but I pressed on and finished the main campaign and really enjoyed it.

One of the best turn based rpgs out there.  Rivals FF Tactics in terms of gameplay and story.  Found myself enjoying this game much more than I thought I would.  The writing is fantastic, but mind you there is a lot of reading.  If you dislike dialogue you may want try something else. I, for one, love a good story so the reading doesn't bother me.

I've never played the Shadowrun tabletop RPG, those aren't my bag. I did love the Shadowrun game on SNES that I played as a kid. This game brings a good blend of nostaglia for that previous title in a similar, but updated look, but it definitely also takes advantage of lessons learned in gaming in the intervening years. Combat in both the real world and while dekking is intuitive and easy to grasp. There are a number of skill tree options to monkey with, but not so many as to require a spreadsheet. Overall I found the game to be a satisfying experience, not terribly difficult, but that's not what I was looking for here anyway. Good times, definitely worth picking up if you enjoyed the old SNES game or the trailer to this one appeals to you.

So point and click, turn-based game play is usually an immediate no for me (I prefer fps tbh) but I was so intrigued by the plot I ended up buying this and I'm so glad I did. It's not voiced (something I didn't realise) but I don't think that hugely detracts from the game. I actually started to enjoy the combat! This is definitely worth a look at if you're as fed up as I am with major games and their ♥♥♥♥♥♥ 'plots'.

Shadowrun Returns is to Shadowrun pen-and-paper RPG as Neverwinter Nights is to Dungeons & Dragons.  That is, it is a perfect videogame GUI for single player adventures.  It is finely and lovingly crafted by the creators of the origional, so you can also count on a faithful game (unlike the Xbox 360 shooter).  It also has tools for creating adventures of your own, and the user-generated content has a thriving community hub.  I hope they make expansions for this game forever, and am personally going to do my part.  I woud recommend this game to anyone.

Shadowrun Returns is not in itself a game. It is a platform that supports the creation and play of Adventures, both developer and community created. Dead Man's Switch" is the initial campaign that you get at purchase and is a well constructed adventure. It has almost all the things you might expect to see and hear in a shadow run adventure. The combat is a xcom esque entertaining and at times very challenging. The characters are interested and likeable. The leveling system is more or less an intuitive waterfall setup. Attributes unlock skills
date:
and skills unlock specializations i.e. Quickness[1] -> marksmen[1] -> rifles[1]. Though the game could do better on conveyance in general. Most important though is the adventure is fun and the game mechanics are solid.

I do have minor grips with some of the unanswered mechanics issues and other game play short comings. But before that I can safely say that if you are a fan of shadowrun or have ever enjoyed playing the paper and pen or older SENS games you will enjoy this one.

** My final recommendation: If you like Shadowrun you will like Shadowrun Returns - Dead Man's Switch **


Now If you are interested in an runners ranting here are some of my misgivings about the game.


-Characters should be persisten between adventures. Starting a new character every adventure is a little disheartening. (This being between Dead Man's Switch and dragonfall)

-Send to stash: sending things to your stash doesn't seem to send said items to your stash.

-Hit Chance: a legendary marksmen shouldn't consistently miss from half a room away just because the target is behind a half cover desk.

-The lack of stealth is a real bummer
