reviewText: If you ever get this game, make sure and get the Dragonfall expansion, it's like a million times better than the base campaign. If shelling out extra for DLC isnt something you're willin to do, the game is pretty mediocre and like 7 hours long. Unless it goes for super cheap during a sale I'd say give it a pass.\n\nThe recommendation is under the assumption you get Dragonfall.

Even if you're not totally familiar with the universe, if you're looking for a great tactical RPG to knock out in a few days? This is perfect. The whole thing is like having one big tasty snack that leaves you wanting more. But that's sort of the downside. It may not give you enough to entirely satisfy you. Which is better than feeling like it's one trudge, but you still wish for more.
The user created levels and junk you can download are okay, but don't really match up to the same quality as the main campaign. That's just my opinion though. And it may not be quite that replayable, or at least not as much as you'd want it to be. Say you decide to be a Street Samurai. This means you probably wont be decking any computers. And while you'll come across a few situations where it'll help, all it really does is save you some time. Same for speech options. They're rare, and don't really offer any change in the conversation.

But in the end, I'd still reccomend it. It still has a great short story to tell and a rich atmosphere. I'd say plan on buying the DLC rather than relying on the user created content to get your additional fix, though. At least until some of the more major projects are legitimately finished.

Shadowrun Returns is a great game.

Think Lord of the Rings meets the Matrix for the setting : orks, elves, trolls, dwarves and regular humans dwell in the shadow of mega-corps, facing the many perils of a cyber-punk low-life. They fight, charm or oustsmart their way around the many dangers of this world with guns, cybertech and magic. The general setting is vibrant and offers a great potential for many stories.

The official first campaign is good, but the excellency comes from the User Generated Contents, some of which are better than the original game. Shadowrun's online community offers a lot of different storylines that make this game virtually immortal : play as an elf shaman, a troll bruiser, a dwarven mage, an ork street samurai or a human cyber pirate (or any combination of them, or a character of your own design), assemble your team of runners and advance through the myriad of high-quality mods. Each character has its advantages and drawbacks, so a balanced team is often the best option, though sometimes brute force, magic or technological capacity can make the difference.

On the gameplay, it is rather intuitive : 50% RPG, 50% turn-by-turn tactical fighting (à la X-Com) with varyinng proportions depending on the mod.

Some classes" are better suited to some roles than others but the progression system allows you to create your own build : do you want your shaman to have proficiency in firearms ?  Do you prefer him to be a pure spellcaster and go mage/shaman ? Do you want him to be extra-tough ? Do prefer to concentrate on invocations and shamanic support spells ? Do you want to sacrifice some of your spellcasting capabilities in favour of cyberware ? All builds are possible and all of them work
date: with various advantages and drawbacks !\n\nThe different races help for the feel of the game but have ultimately little impact gameplay-wise apart at the very begining or at the very end of a campaign. Choosing to be a tough troll or a gracefull elf will give you some minor changes in starting stats and a different ultimate potential
recommended: but for most of the game the different races don't really matter.\n\nOverall
hoursPlayed: this great game is made awesome thanks to the online community (most of which is here on Steam)."

reviewText: Really fun. Different from the Genesis and SNES games and more reminiscent of an old school CRPG. Some of the situations wil have you grinning at the deviousness. Play on the harder modes for a better time.

Its hard for me to put into words just how great this game is, I honestly can't sing enough of its praises to be truthful. The entire game is rich and full of atmosphere, really setting the mood for the setting it is placed in. The game had me firmly in its grasp the entire time I played it and not once did it let me go, never breaking character or form in a way that jarred me out of the experience.

The game's character creation is really straight forward and easy to understand and especially flexible, so if you find yourself dislikeing the path you set yourself on but happen to like another class as long as you do so early enough you can more or less cross class and still be rather effective!

The game is turn based so if that's your stick hop right on in! It's challenging, but not in the punishing way.  I've never had something in the game bad happen to me that was anything less than poor performance on my part. It's never made me feel like I've been cheated out of a win or into a death. Only that I made a stupid move and ended up dead or lossing the battle becuase I failed a requirement.

Every character I ran into was full of life and unique in their own right, I've never met someone in the game I've even actively disliked! Well, save some of the villians and that was only in the sense of. Jeez

My first impression of this game was really great and i was really impressed by the story wirting , art direction and character building but as i progressed through the game its flaws have became more apparent .
Story wirting is good through out the whole game and the writer/s seems like a knowledgeable person but i was really surprised when i noticed spelling and grammer mistakes! For me it wasn't a big problem since English is not my native language but i think many native-English gamers will find it annoying .
The gameplay machanics are good but have small problems that can be annoying at times .Some of them are technical (like when you set the character to overwatch a certain enemy/area and then it goes out of the previously set range and waste a bullet and an AP point) and some of them are design flaws (like being forced to traverse a whole floor in battle mode even if there is no enemy left) .
For the game design in general i really wished that the developers have reused the previously visted locations for side-missions to increase the game time and value because in the end this is an RPG game and not COD .

This game have its flaws but i was able to look past them and enjoy it .That's why i'm recommending it .

Game itself was a very nice change, enjoyed thoroughly. Looks to be a lot of third party content easily available through Steam Workshop. Dragonfall expansion/DLC is even better. Really easy to lose track of time if you immerse yourself into it, but also allows you to multi-task and watch a movie etc if you want to. Will definitely play through again, as it allows you to take different paths through the game.

I played the old SNES game to death so I had to play this, and loved it! Turn based strategy isn't usually my bag, but I ended up really enjoying the game system here. And it was great to just settle back in to the writing and setting of Shadowrun. Cyberpunk ridiculousness at its finest -- and I really enjoyed the plot! I'll definitely get the DLC at some point.

reviewText: absolutely excellent all around.
Good story, fun turn based combat, lots of character options.
Pretty good I'd say 7.5 out of 10

I was never one for isometric RPG's however I did a bit of research on this game and what attracted me the most was its setting. The gritty, dark, futuristic fantasy setting is portrayed quite well in the game in terms of its art style, environmental design and the text based descriptions of your encounters. By itself the default campaign can seem quite restricted. As though its trying to give you the illusion that your decisions impacts everything differently when its more than likely going to play out the same way. However I was still compelled to go on because I found the story somewhat interesting and simply enjoyed getting engrossed in the world Shadowrun Returns puts you in.  The combat itself is simple but it doesn't seem like it would get repetitive fast for me.\n\nWhat makes this game worth it for me though would be the wide array of user made content I see int he Steam workshop. Some of them seem well made and I intend to put more hours into them once I'm through the main campaign.

4/5\n\nThe mechanics are just crunchy enough to keep things interesting while remaining uncomplicated and the base story, 'The Dead Man's Switch', is quite an engaging narrative to play through. That said, my main outstanding complaint is that some character builds just aren't made relevant enough to be much fun - namely I would advise against playing as a dedicated Decker.

This game is absolutely awesome. It takes the rpg elements of the original Fallout 1 and 2 and mixes it with some of the combat mechanics of XCOM: Enemy Unknown/Within. The characters and world are wonderful, giving you that silver lining to a dystopian society. I picked this game up and logged 5 hours nonstop after starting.

If you like story driven RPGs or turn-based tactics games, get this game.

Edit: I don't mean to sound like I'm advertising it, this mod completes the game. Subscribe to the Shadowrun Unlimited mod in the Steam Workshop for an open world, borderline endless (so far as I can tell) adventure. You pick the contracts, explore an open city as you please, and work your way up the chain (unlock higher tier missions = more money = better apartment & equipment vendors). With this mod, I may never stop playing this game.

It's ok....

I wish the story did not hold your hand like it did. They should of when with more Hitchcock and less Southpark Crab people.  The story when from Neon SIgn pointing at the bad guy, to out of left field plot line.  Noire, Mystery was lacking to this cyberpunk story.

NPC AI was alittle buggy every now and then.  A few times the Enemy NPC ran to an empty room then ran back, and they would switch targets when your health got low.  Again to much hand holding, even on Hard.

Graphics was nice and clean, but seeing the same character models on every corner was heartbreaking for this Kickstarter game that promise to bring back the good ole days.

If you've ever played 2nd Edition Shadowrun this is a huge nostalgia trip - if you haven't it's still damn fun.

The majority of the game plays out like an old-school text-based RPG like Fallout (no voice actors required) and will have you investigating the death of an old friend through a variety of standard 2050s Seattle backdrops.

Combat, when it happens, is very similar to XCOM: Enemy Unknown. Each character has a set number of action points that they can use each turn to move, shoot, cast spells, control drones, etc. Normal difficulty shouldn't pose much of a threat (I think I've been killed twice) so once you have the mechanics of it down I'd suggest playing through on Hard or better.

Slight spoiler for the main story: make sure you put some points into Shotguns.

This game is amazing. It mixes classic tactical RPG-gameplay like Fallout 2 with a world that most closely reminds me of Blade Runner and Deus Ex. The storyline is very well written, with a lot of consequential decisionmaking and characters full of life.\nA must buy for every true RPG fan.

reviewText: This games story is very engaging and well written, the combat is identical to Xcom in many ways and the DLC is even better than the original story. 10/10

Great game but a little shorter than what I was expecting.  Went thru the whole thing with no walk thru in 11 hours. It is very straight foward no real branching paths or much of a world to explore. I pick the game up on sale for $4.00 and if you get it for that price I'd say it's worth it but would not pay much more than that.  Have not messed around with the workshop so maybe there is a lot more content.

I have been role playing 4th edition for a few years now and i have to say when i backed this and SR online i had really high hopes especially because of the people who were making it. i got to say SRO still needs alot of work but it is getting there.
now SRR is a game to behold, the first one holds up well and as a game is good but lacked something i could not put my finger on. the customization is good even if it ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ up the skills making it possible to be just about anything you want to be.
i understand that games have limits and as a player you want to be anything possible and since the SNES does allow you to be just about anything as well i will let that slide.
Turn base combat works well with the amount of players you will be playing with and who you are up against and even if it might give you the impression that its slow paced the way it carries itself will feel very fluid and fast you will be scratching at the keys hoping that lost shotgun shell wont finish off one of your runners.

Now let me get to Dragonfall, this game has it all and i am still so thrilled to be playing it, the runs feel like a typical milk run but it will always turn south and bad things become worse everytime. the plot devices for characters is rich and want you to keep looking for more even if they are side characters. this truely feels like a shadowrun game and it should be enjoyed to the fullest as a gamer and as a role player.

the feel and atmosphere of SR is there and if you are a role player yourself deffently give it a go you wont be disapointed, but if you feel SRR isnt as its holding up to be then you must get dragonfall trust me!!!
The Campaign provided is short, but then again, this was designed with the community toolbox in mind. Pick this up if you want an rpg system that you can sink your teeth into!

The base game is decent; the DLC is very good. Base game introduces you to all the game mechanics and is a good if not particularly deep game. The DLC on the other hand has a great plot that lends credibilty to the various runs your crew goes on, some great twists and turns, er, and also has some battles that are (potentially) cruelly unfair, awful, and frustrating.

I just had trouble with the one battle, but I read that others had trouble with one or two others. I expect that it depends on play style and the party you bring. The battles often have some sort of interesting twist or surprise that makes them really interesting, but depending on your party and playstyle the same twist can make it very frustrating instead. Maybe the occasional rage quit is the price you pay for the cool surprises. :)

In summary:
a) strongly recommended, worth buying just to play the DLC, and
b) AUGH. AUGH AUGH AUGH. AUGH MMMWAAAH! AUGH! DIE! DIE! DIE! KILL! WHY AM I DOING THIS TO MYSELF? ISN'T THIS SUPPOSED TO BE FUN??? OK calm down, let's try it again.

Four stars. A generally great game and totally worth your money. Expect 1 (and possibly 2  or 3 depending on what party you bring) really unfair battles in the DLC. :)  No, really, it's a little frustrating, but you care because it's good. Just buy it.

reviewText: While lacking in length (and to some degree depth), it certainly doesnt lack for atmosphere. The world of Shadowrun and in particular the SNES game is very eveident and the game itself is a real pleasure to play. While the campaign may be short, theres a lot of fun to be had playing and i doubt anyone will regret buying it.

This game totally rocks!!  It's a little old, and if you're looking for graphics and cosmetics, go elsewhere, cause those are things you won't find here.  But it has everything else.  Lots of interactivity, like you just don't find:  a lot of the decisions you make for how you say things are just your own flair, don't make a difference, but decisions you make in game impact things early on and forward.  Some of these decisions, naturally, Shadowrun being a logical universe, require you to be able to do it-- so if you don't have the skill in question high enough, it's not an option-- but not to worry, there are more than two ways to skin a cat sometimes, and there's pretty much always going to be more than one.  Sometimes, that involves creativity- like buying coffee if you figure out a solution for a street junkie who wants more money than you (may) have, even if you talk him down in price (though you might have enough) but is too out of it to be able to get down to the cafe for himself, so, insert errand, you pay less than you would have doing it straightforwardly-- though it's the future, and real coffee is still pretty pricey (for coffee).

You get money multiple ways for different things, including of course selling loot-- but so far in my playing the game there's more of an emphasis on selling mission items, specifically software you stole, and by completing jobs and/or tasks.

Tasks:  this is also how you level up.  In this game, trust me from the start, you *really* want to explore the world around you.  There are people to interact with you, and as often as not, the things they want from you can give you a karma point.  You don't know what will give you karma points, but it's not hard enough to figure out looking around and seeing things you can help people with helps.  Karma would seem an odd name for the resource for levelling, but it's actually not, because you can do things like get a junkie help-- which you hear more about later if you do.  Again, you can pick how you go about getting her to get help, too:   do you play it higher-than-thou, at least that's how I see it, do you talk logic to her, do you scare her-- you might have to do two of those at least, actually, but I only played through once.  Just on the earlier point.

But back to karma.  You get karma for beating mission objectives, which again do not just come up without chatting, looking into things and such, clicking on things to figure out what's going on in the world around you-- if interactivity does not appeal to you, this is not the game for you; it is not simply fighting.  If it does, it's more complicated than I make it sound in experience, because there are so many different things to interact with... it would be hard to categorize.  *Ahem!*  You explore, you complete tasks, you get karma....

... and you level up!!  Leveling up takes up a lot of karma, and there's a whole lot to level up, so you have to pick and choose, but a lot of it you're just going to forget about anyway, because your character isn't specialized in hacking- oh you included that?  S/he is a super crappy fighter then, at least as far as I've gotten, but okay, that's what you get when you want to hack computers instead of being a gunslinger.

I kinda didn't like the extensive use of spell-like systems in this game to start with, but now that I've gotten more used to it, I just want to go all out when I have the credits and buy like everything and use it all.   The spell-systems are different, though they don't all get called that (there are three of them) and they're not as out of place as you may be thinking.  If you read about the game, bear in mind, there are guns and computers and hackers, but there are also trolls and ogres and dragons.  Just sayin'.

Oh.... the dragons are bad*** and you literally don't mess with them.  Taking down a dragon takes an army, not a small unit, generally speaking, and in this futuristic society the dragons wiped out large bodies of people before getting taken out... not all of them have been.   All of this is in the lifetime-recent past of the living, some of it having started *it's true* since after the game came out, presumably, but at any rate also before 2014, which is when I'm writing this.

Man, I've spent a fortune it seems on MMOs that I got sick of.... this game cost me under $5 while on sale and I can't get enough of it so far.  I'll get tired of it, too, but I'm definitely looking for another game for nothing again when I get tired of it... graphics aren't bad for being old and cheap budget, and I like reading the text better than listening, but oh, there is a lot of reading, did I say that?  lol... you have to read the conversations, no voice acting... it's all low-budget... just straight-up good creativity is what makes it such an awesome game.  Modding community too, though I haven't tried their work yet, no reason-- still playing through my first campaign.

So I highly recommend this game.... it should run on your computer if it's not a fossil, though I could be wrong, and I apologize if so.... this is the first review I've written for Steam, and the game definitely deserved some credits."

It was a pretty cool game. My favorite aspect was just the atmosphere. I'm into that techy almost post-apocalyptic feel. Everything was edgy and I really felt I had to rely on my wits and street knowledge. However I was really confused about the classes and karma upgrades. I felt like I needed to take some time to sit down and go through each section to understand what upgrades were good to get or worthless for my character. Another issue was probably the fact that you'd have a big advantage being a decker. A bunch of quests had only special decker options. Since I wasn't playing as a decker, I could almost never take those options. In general a lot of character development felt a bit off and weighed to one or two specific classes. I might try some of the workshop stories and see how those go, but all in all, I had a lot of fun, but it just stopped abruptly.

Shadowrun Returns was a game I bought on a whim during the summer sale. I had heard good things about the cult classic original so I decided to check this out. I was not disappointed. A deep, lush, and depressing sci-fi fantasy noir world. Many different skill trees for multiple playthroughs and play styles. And an interesting narrative. I got this for less that $4, but it's worth the $15 price tag.

This game is great.

Very much liked the story, both Dead Man's Switch and the DLC Dragonfall, and the ease of picking up and playing the game.  Between Dead Man's Switch and Dragonfall, I liked the latter better.  I fell Dragonfall has more options and replay to see how your choices change the course of events.
I liked it, it really did feel short though, which is my only criticism.

This has been an interesting experience! Isometric RPGs have been rapidly winning my heart back even since ME 3 and this one was a fresh change from the normal recipe.

The skill system is nicely portrayed, gameplay is fun and with a lot of choices and the story brilliant enough to keep you invested ( don't expect crazy or unexpected plot twists here )

My two major cons here are the general linearity of the game , which doesn't allow much on the exploration department and the lack of plentiful side quests (which probably goes side by side with my first complain) This game CRIES for side questing and the characters it introduces are SO WELL portrayed that it's arguably a crime that there is no further development with them or some involving quests to further enjoy them in action (Coyote's quest for example should have been done for more characters!) There is your occasional side quest , but they are SOOO few that it makes you feel sad moving on to the next chapter like this. Finally i was REALLY bummed by the length of the main campaign .. I mean okay i understand that you guys were betting on the UGC (user generated content) to maximize replayability but really that short ??? You could have made an at least +20 hours on the Dead man's switch . Oh well..

I'd say I'm only about halfway through this game so far, but I am loving every minute of it! The visuals and art-style look very nice and I love the cyberpunk themed setting. Combat mechanics are very simplistic and work similar to xcom games, but its rpg elements are very in-depth and enough to compensate for its simplistic combat gameplay.\n\nThe highlight of this game for me is its story-telling. If you don't mind reading (there are no voice actors) and enjoy a good sci-fi conspiracy story (think deus ex) you will enjoy this!

TL;DR Not at all like Shadowrun on 360, great text-based story, must get

I played the Shadowrun deathmatch spinoff for Xbox 360 years ago and it has always had a special place in my heart.  The combat was refreshing and very fun.  It had fleeting little story but I was intrigued by it nonetheless.

It's funny how much of a 180 this game is compared to the spinoff.

The combat is an ersatz XCOM and not really satisfying.  I played on normal so of course I wasn't playing the game to its full potential.  The combat was pretty boring and felt like an afterthought.

BUT WAIT!  This game doesn't suck!  In huge contrast to the only other Shadowrun game I have played this game has a story!  And what a story it is.  The plot is positively enthralling (hehe).  Sorry you'll get it when you buy this magnificent game.    The plot is split into two acts, of which the first I believe is stronger.  The first act is a pretty standard whodunit and the second is... I don't know if I missed out on some backstory from the tabletop game, but it's a lot to take in.  But sometimes it's nice to be overwhelmed by a story, you know?  The characters, dialogue and text descriptions (setting, items, etc.) is really where the game shines.  The characters are interesting (I found myself talking to every single one at every opportunity) and feel real.  Their personalities don't feel fake and nobody does a complete character change halfway through as an excuse for a plot twist which is common in games.  The dialogue is witty and enjoyable.  Sadly there are no voice actors, but it doesn't take away too much from the immersion.

There's just something special about the written word and its power to completely immerse you in a story.  The writers for this game are truly skilled, as the settings described are so much more than what I could ever gain from just seeing it.  There's such a huge emphasis on graphics these days that I think people get caught up in it and forget that sight is only one of many senses.  The written word describes all of them.  Sight, smell, sound, touch, you name it and it can be described.  I hope this game succeeds and more developers join this niche of text-based RPG, as there is truly no better way to immerse the player than to write down what you want them to know.

I give this game a 7/10 but it is really a must buy for me.  The story itself makes the game well worth the price when it's on sale.

If you're looking for a gritty turn-based strategy game in a similar vein to that of XCOM or Omerta, then this is your game. It's set in a dystopian future, the game merges fantasy races into a human world with a cyberpunk setting. The plot has you constantly moving from action to action in what starts out as a simple detective story, but quickly changes gear into a much deeper, darker plot.\n\nThe game is fun. I recommend it and rate it 8/10.
Was a backer and wasn't disappointed, but I could see how some would be.  Kind of linear, but captured some of the feel.  Bought the DLC, MUCH better.  Would reccommend.
This is a very well made  game.  It does a good job of taking a pen and paper RPG and making a fun and enjoyable PC game.

Shadowrun Returns is an adaptation of the classic cyberpunk tabletop pen and paper RPG. Set in an alternative history future where magic has returned to the world, elves, dwarves, trolls, and orks live side by side with humans in dense urban cities, and corporations are a law unto themselves; the game centers around the segment of humanity who makes their living in the shadows, the runners. Hacker, mercenary, detective, sorcerer, where there is a job that needs doing, there will be someone willing to get paid to do it.

The game itself is a single player, turn-based strategy RPG, utilizing 3/4 isometric perspective with 3D character models set against sprite based backgrounds. The sprite backgrounds are static and well done, while the character designs are somewhat poorly textured with resolution below that which the majority of modern systems could easily handle; belying the limited budget the company had to work with. Gameplay takes the form of point and click interaction with the world map and carries over directly into combat, utilizing the same environments. Combat is somewhat klunky, as there are problems with the interaction of the courser and corners of the movement field.

The game itself is, however, merely a platform. It is in reality intended for players to build and share their own Shadowrun campaigns, and the full game editor comes included with the base game as well as a professionally developed campaign. Thanks to Steam Works, player campaigns are free, though professionally developed campaigns will be sold as DLC as they become available. Sadly there is no multiplayer option what-so-ever, crippling one of the intregral elements of the pen-and-paper game.

Overall, the game's campaign will run you around 12 hours, and is a good buy if you can get it on sale, for any enthusiast of turn-based strategy RPGs.
Fell in love with this game very quickly. Loved the original, and this one has a D&D kind of feel with it's turn-based combat, but still plays like Shadowrun. Wish it was more open world though.

Probably too short (10 hours for me, and I take my sweet time in such games) to be worth the 15 euros, unless you intend on making intensive use of the steam workshop.\n\nHowever if it's on sale at a low price, go for it! It was really fun.
if you love cyber punk themes you will love this game , i leave it at that. also the story is decent.\n\noverall : 8/10

reviewText:
Shadowrun was a breath of fresh air for me.

IAmongst hordes of MOBAs and shooters, an classic RPG like Shadowrun definetly stands out. Intriguing setting, fusion between science fiction and fantasy create an unique noir-ish atmosphere of futuristic coroprate-ruled world. The closest game to this that has been released recently is probably only Deus Ex: Human Revolution.
Great writing, beautiful system and stylish graphics makes you wish to play it again and again. However, main campaign, while   engagin and entertaining is relatively short. Luckily, with the integration of Steam Workshop, that could become a reality, with steady flow of well-crafted user-created content.

Can't wait to play it again in my free time.

reviewText: absolutely excellent all around.
Good story, fun turn based combat, lots of character options.

Great salute to a high school tabletop favorite.  I still haven't completed the provided storyline, but am deeply taken by the depth and breadth of the episode.  I look forward to trying out the story's of others and am contimplating writing one or two of my own in the future.

Pros The Cyberpunk-meets-Fantasy-Magic set in the real-world near-future aesthetic is great.
The way the stats are balanced leaves the class-race combos open, and encourages exploration of different options/layouts. I just wish there was a way to respecc. Maybe there is later in the game.
I love the tactical, turn-based combat.
Cons The single angle of the camera gets a little annoying in combat; e.g. if you've got an ally standing directly beneath/infront of an enemy, you can accidentally target your ally because their hitbox overlaps the enemy's. If I could rotate the camera to a different angle, that'd solve my biggest gripe with the game
The first campaign (Dead Man's Switch) is interesting, but rather slow-paced. Haven't tried the expansion campgain or any of the user generated content yet.
All in all, it's a fun tactical, turn-based, text-driven RPG. The character creation options are pretty robust -- not so much in terms of appearances, but in terms of class selection and creation. It's easy to start out with one of the game's premade archetypes and expand out into other disciplines as you get the feel for the game, or to just stick with a single discipline. I don't know how well either works comparatively because I haven't played long enough. The story of the first campaign moves a little slow; they do a good job of tying the tutorial stuff into the story without breaking immersion, but that's kind of what slows it down.

One of the most influenceable cyberpunk turn-based game ever created is BACK. With lot of RPG element, creat your own hero from scratch including: races, skill tree, class and many more. New player welcome and old player will be thrill about this new upgrate!
Really good dialogues, neatly written and well plotted.

This is a great game!

reviewText: Amazing game! Shut up and buy it already.

Definitely worth $15.   I hate reading dialog but this game made it enjoyable.   Well written!  Also the combat was fun.  It was a fun game and I recomend it.  It isn't a long game but I'm not sure you would want it any longer... it is just right.\n\nA good long weekend game.

I absolutely love this game. Although it lacks in the free roaming aspect that many RPG’s do well in the story is extremely immersive and the characters are interesting and at times frustrating. The old-school isometric view lends itself well to Shadowrun and the lighting when in urban areas sets a great tone for the dark cyber punk world the game is set in.  The character creation isn’t quite deep enough in regards to ascetics but more than makes up for this in the skill tree and I found myself fiddling with the skills for ages whilst envisioning what kind of cyber punk badass I was going to be. The combat is turn based which I found very refreshing, as I am a massive fan of turn based strategy games, and I found the whole process of finding cover and blasting the enemy very entertaining.\nTo sum up if you’re not a fan of deep story driven games with lots of text and long spells between the action then this game isn’t for you, although I would recommend anyone to embark on this story……you won’t be sorry.\n

Amazing game in the Shadowrun realm. I was a huge fan of both the SNES and Genesis Shadowrun games and this did not disapoint.
Cool story and great customization on you're character.

Highly recommend both main game and DLC content.
Great game, loved every bit of it. Will play it again.
10/10 love everything about it

Gameplay is quite good once you get into it, i bought while it was on sale, so i think it was a bargain, however i would not pay full price as i completed the game in one playthrough in 16.5 hrs, i would have liked to see more content and a bit more choice as the game basically plays itself as you cannot deviate from the path chosen :)
It's late .. I didn't want to write much, except to recommend this game =)

Great with just the core game, brilliant with the expansion. I am looking forward to working through some community mods next, if the storylines are any good this could be keeping me occupied for some time!

Frustrating lack of explanation with game mechanics. No real tutorial, no real explanation for how things work.
The game feels very much unpolished.
Despite that, the game is still fun. I'm a big fan of these types of games though.

May get a lot of mileage out of it due to user generated content.

It has been a long time since we had an actual Shadowrun game and this game delivers big time. The look and atmosphere of 2050's Seattle is spot on. Even if that were the only thing it had going for it, I'd still recommend it. However, the actual gameplay is great as well. The story is engaging, there's a fair amount of customization, and the controls are easy to figure out. I can't say enough good things about this game.
Great game!

I have enjoyed the Shadowrun universe for a couple decades and feel this really hits the mark for creating that world.
While I completely enjoyed Dead Man Switch playing Dragonfall only highlighted the flaws I saw in DMS. Everything I was ambivalent about with DMS was rectified and improved.
If you were on the fence after playing DMS then rest assured, Dragonfall is awesome and blows DMS out of the water. This is more than just game mechanics and tweaks. The story telling is better, conversation options are vastly improved, missions are more varied, NPCs are more than just mission givers and your squad mates have personality and history to uncover as you get closer to them.
In short I love this game and can't wait for future releases.

It's a great turn based style RPG. While it has some limitations on the amount of control of gear we can get for our NPC allies, it they are generally decent enough in their designated roles. The story is great with good story telling and challenges.
Great game, 88 hours of pure fun... please release more dlcs, better with voice and video cutscenes

Sometimes you feel like shooting a guy in the face. Other times you feel like amplifying your fists with magic power and pummeling an enemy to death. Oh look, I'm hacking your system and fighting inside the Matrix.\n\nWhy am I in love wth a troll? Damn. Dragonfall expansion really shines in the narrative. Highly addictive learning about your fellow group of misfits.

I'd say I'm only about halfway through this game so far, but I am loving every minute of it! The visuals and art-style look very nice and I love the cyberpunk themed setting. Combat mechanics are very simplistic and work similar to xcom games, but its rpg elements are very in-depth and enough to compensate for its simplistic combat gameplay.\n\nThe highlight of this game for me is its story-telling. If you don't mind reading (there are no voice actors) and enjoy a good sci-fi conspiracy story (think deus ex) you will enjoy this!

TL;DR Not at all like Shadowrun on 360, great text-based story, must get

I played the Shadowrun deathmatch spinoff for Xbox 360 years ago and it has always had a special place in my heart.  The combat was refreshing and very fun.  It had fleeting little story but I was intrigued by it nonetheless.

It's funny how much of a 180 this game is compared to the spinoff.

The combat is an ersatz XCOM and not really satisfying.  I played on normal so of course I wasn't playing the game to its full potential.  The combat was pretty boring and felt like an afterthought.

BUT WAIT!  This game doesn't suck!  In huge contrast to the only other Shadowrun game I have played this game has a story!  And what a story it is.  The plot is positively enthralling (hehe).  Sorry you'll get it when you buy this magnificent game.    The plot is split into two acts, of which the first I believe is stronger.  The first act is a pretty standard whodunit and the second is... I don't know if I missed out on some backstory from the tabletop game, but it's a lot to take in.  But sometimes it's nice to be overwhelmed by a story, you know?  The characters, dialogue and text descriptions (setting, items, etc.) is really where the game shines.  The characters are interesting (I found myself talking to every single one at every opportunity) and feel real.  Their personalities don't feel fake and nobody does a complete character change halfway through as an excuse for a plot twist which is common in games.  The dialogue is witty and enjoyable.  Sadly there are no voice actors, but it doesn't take away too much from the immersion.

There's just something special about the written word and its power to completely immerse you in a story.  The writers for this game are truly skilled, as the settings described are so much more than what I could ever gain from just seeing it.  There's such a huge emphasis on graphics these days that I think people get caught up in it and forget that sight is only one of many senses.  The written word describes all of them.  Sight, smell, sound, touch, you name it and it can be described.  I hope this game succeeds and more developers join this niche of text-based RPG, as there is truly no better way to immerse the player than to write down what you want them to know.

I give this game a 7/10 but it is really a must buy for me.  The story itself makes the game well worth the price when it's on sale.

If you're looking for a gritty turn-based strategy game in a similar vein to that of XCOM or Omerta, then this is your game. It's set in a dystopian future, the game merges fantasy races into a human world with a cyberpunk setting. The plot has you constantly moving from action to action in what starts out as a simple detective story, but quickly changes gear into a much deeper, darker plot.\n\nThe game is fun. I recommend it and rate it 8/10.
Was a backer and wasn't disappointed, but I could see how some would be.  Kind of linear, but captured some of the feel.  Bought the DLC, MUCH better.  Would reccommend.
good ol' 2D rpg

Great start to a modern era Shadowrun game.  Definitely captures the feel of the pen and paper game while holding on to traditional video game RPG ideas.  Can't wait to try out the editor and play the next campaign!

The story, definitely. Plenty of twists and turns. I daily kept coming back to play the game. I was saddened that I finished it in 13 hrs+ but I'm definitely getting dragonfall? the expansion. And then there's a Steam Workshop for this game! The guns for this turn based rpg do so make a satisfying boom, at least for me. I was also really pleased that I could customize my character the way I wanted. I started as a non magical street samurai but I got enough points over the course of the game to specialize in another skillset as well. You can go into spellcasting, summoning, cyberdecking or drone rigging. If it isn't obvious by now, I like this game.

Loved the original as a kid. Wasn't overly impressed when I first purchased this, but the graphical updates have created a better environment for a more immersive experience. Wished voice acting didn't cost and arm and a leg...adding a little bit of this would make this game great. BUT, the combat is solid, writing is good, and community is strong (for user mods). I would recommend this game on sale. Make sure to grab the dlc to this game. It's brings new elements to a campaign that are a must IMHO.

I have to admit, this game was a surprise. i'm really enjoying it, which, considering the reviews, I didn't expect to. It's very grindy with the running around and the dialogue, more like a visual novel than a game, and the combat is stupid hard, but all in all, I'm having a good time with it.\n\nBasically, don't go into this game expecting an action rpg, or the decision impacts of an open world rpg. It's an old-school turn based combat RPG, and it does that exceedingly well.

I loved the old console game, this is a blast from the past. I would love to see this world taken up like the Fall Out series and made in to a Shadow Run game with Fall Out Vegas style of play. I did not like the new decker style of play, thought the old one was better. Still love to see so many fellow gamers getting in to crafting mods and story lines. Fun and well worth it.

I'm a lost soul. I used to love games. Now i just buy them and don't play them. No time, work, kids, life. Only thing I seem to enjoy is Civ5 and the occasional adventure (Gemini Rue, Book of Unwritten Tales). Otherwise everything seems like a waste of time within the hour. Bought this game yesterday. Seems to bring me out of my funk. I'm IN it.Longed for that for a long time and the time seemes to have arrived. YES!!

Graphics - 4/5

A fantastic pre-rendered world that looks fantastic almost everywhere. There are some flickering issues in some areas and some of the larger creatures aren't high resolution friendly.

Sound - 3/5

Nothing incredibly memorable, BUT, it is absolutely perfect for the setting and really sets the mood of this bleak futuristic world.

Gameplay - 5/5

Best tactical RPG I've ever played. You can make whatever kind of character you want. My character used nothing but his fists and knuckle weapons and he ended up being a badass knocking security bots out with a single punch. The combat itself is awesome, fast paced and controls really well. One thing that I noticed though was I feel like the percentages are a little off for the accuracy ratings, I feel like I've rarely hit anything lower than 60 percent.

Story - 4.5/5

This is a review of the Dragonfall story. You follow a group of shadowrunners led by your character, and the game really makes you familiar with everyone. All species of sentient beings have their own ways of speaking and there are very little stereotypical characters. Strong female leads, strong male leads, and all around strong side characters. Dead Man's Switch overplayed the in world slang a little bit too much, but Dragonfall made it very easy to get what certain words mean.

Overall: 4/5
A game that realy incorporates what a good old scholld RPG means.\nTruly great 10/10.
Really great game. I would recommend it to anyone who likes cyberpunk, detective stories and turn based strategy games like XCOM: Enemy Unknown.
Awesome game. Really liked the look and the music. The story was fun, and the Berlin expansion was even better than the original. Looking forward to more!
Haven't played the original, but I've had my eye on this for awhile. Highly recommended for fans of turn-based strategy and/or RPG's. Make sure you get the Dragonfall expansion.

You might look at this game and sneer at it's graphics or gameplay, but the simple truth is that the sheer potential of the Shadowrun Universe and the modding community raises the lasting value ten or twenty fold. Most of my play time has been spent playing workshop content rather than the official campaigns.

Recommend you buy the Dragon Fall DLC, the campaign is excellent (vastly superior to the original Dead Man's Switch) and the new functionalities added to the engine are used in a lot of the workshop content.

Must own for any Shadowrun fun out there, and anyone with an interest in great story telling and lore should check it out.

If you love anything cyberpunk, then is the closest thing you'll get to that atmosphere. The music is gritty and has that pulse that reminds me of reading Neuromancer. Great intro to those that might want to try out the actual Pen and Paper version, and a good lesson for any runner to see how a campaign should be run.

Shadowrun is easily the best story-driven tactical turn-based adventure-combat game I've played since Fallout 2. The original campaign (Dead Man's Switch) is great, the second (Dragonfall) is fantastic, and the tons and tons of UGC campaigns available are full of gems that easily rival the official publications. I suggest trying out Nightmare Harvest for a great & funny story, and Shadowrun Ultimate for a semi-MMO player-driven work-your-way-up" open world experience."

Lives up to the classic I played years ago. Not as improved as it could be, very dated if your comparing it to open world and procedurally generated. Even look back to Diablo or fallout tatics it is still a bit clunky. I am really hoping for a building assault, muti floor action. Where one of my runners gets knocked out a window but grapples his way back in maybe a floor or two lower. Did you guys play some new XCOM recently? can you imagine a decker across the street in another bulding maybe with a sniper and a squad fighting their way up to be in a cross fire another runner team on another mission. will it be enemy of my enemy or just another target.
The included campaign is decent enough, but the game's coolest aspect is the level editor and the workshop campaigns.

I started playing in order to check out the game.  The first think I noticed was that without going into the settings, movement of my mouse from the game to my desktop was seamless.  As I went on, I noticed other little things that I normally needed to tweak, I didn't.  They just worked.  But more importantly, as I went on, I was transported to a time many years ago in the story, in the environment, in the game play.  If you loved Shadowrun on the SNES, you'll love this.  And if you didn't know about it, you'll find a new love.  The best Kickstarter I've backed, and one of the best games that I've played.  Definitely Recommended.
Wow, I am blown away by this one folks. The main campain is solid, but the user created stuff in the workshop is amazing!
A very cool framework for a very underwhelming story.

Exactly what I wanted from a Shadowrun game. I only wish the official content and DLC were longer. There are some really good mod missions that are very fun. My only complaint is that you can't take your original character through dragonfall, but based on the dragonfall story it makes sense.

This game is well rendered and the story is very interesting. I'm happy to have supported a non-mainstream game like this one. It would have gone from good to amazing with even a little bit of voice acting.\n\nThe length of the game was just under 20 hours. Acceptable length compared to what I was expecting. It's not really replayable for me because I got to experience different types of characters when creating my party for various missions.

Very good RPG, the combat is similar to Fire Emblem, and is probably the game with the combat closest to XCOM: EU. The combat isn't as deep as it is in either games, very story focused, lots of dialogue to read. If you don't mind having to read a lot of dialogue (It's comparable to some old cRPG's with the amount), then it's definitely for you. Also, lots of references to places in Washington state if you're from there.

I had a good time with this game.  It brought back many fond memories of the pen & paper adventures of my youth.  It's not a 100% recreation of those rules but it is very close.  The story is very linear but interesting.  Is it the greatest RPG story ever told? No.  Did I have fun and feel like my time was well spent? Yes.  Overall, if you are a Shadowrun fan, it's well worth the price.

RPG elements are done very well.  Some simplification.  Magic and Cyberware aren't exactly like the book, but mods are working to make them more similar.  Physical Adepts are very different, but still vialable and even fun.  They also are balanced even in stock format.  Both Deadman's Switch and Dragonfall are wonderful campaigns and great fun.

Gameplay is like XCom (but watered down), and it's pretty featureless.  However, there's some good (nothing great, yet) user generated maps and campaigns, and the story that it comes with is pretty great if you like Shadowrun.  Not worth $20, but if you find it for under $10 it's worth it.

If you like cyberpunk, roleplaying and tactical gameplay, boy is this game for you. While the original campaign has some problems, it is still worth a playthrough and with a DLC campaign player made campaigns available, there is a lot of other good stuff to find once your done. Or you could just make a totally new character and just do it all again.

It reminds me of the original fallout games, a good story, environment, and well thought out tactics. I have only played a bit so far but I am looking foward to playing the story all the way through.\n\nI also really like the fact it is modable by the community so the options for gameplay are as endless as the players.

I can't really add much as I haven't been playing long but what I have seen so far I've loved to bits. This is my kind of game! The graphics are absolutely fantastic. That really matters here as it creates such an atmosphere. The writing is also very good. I haven't felt the need to skip anything so far. So really I just wanted to put out a quick review that's got the bottom line.. If you enjoy turn based, story driven Sci-Fi, then you came to the right place, jack right in and enjoy!

The core campaign here, Dead Man's Switch, is awful.  It serves as an introduction to the mechanics and, to a much lesser extent, the setting of Shadowrun.  The DLC/expansion Dragonfall, however, is absolutely fantastic, and is completely unrelated to the core campaign.  It's one of the better written RPGs I've ever played.  The characters are great, the story is interesting, the decisions are difficult, and although the epilogue" is a little weak
date: the overall ending was solid.  I heartily recommend Dragonfall to any RPG enthusiast and especially to anyone who has ever been curious to explore the Shadowrun setting."

reviewText:
Besides Mass Effect, its been a very long time since I've found a roleplaying game that I've really enjoyed.

Honestly, Shadowrun Returns blew away my expectations, especially since I didn't really have any going into it. I knew that it was based off a classic sci-fi tabletop RPG, but that was about it.

The first campaign, The Deadman's Switch, draws you into the world of Shadowrun very well, introduces you to some characters, and generally how the game works and feels. It's a nice introduction to the game, but it does have a few things that annoyed and irked me. Especially the linearity of it all. It was one story the whole way through, with not many different ways to approach things, or side quests to take up your time.

That's why I recommend getting the Dragonfall expansion with it. I've played the expansion for three or four hours at this point, and all of my problems with the original game have been taken care of, as far as I can tell. There are a lot more things put in place to sidetrack you, and I really like that.

But, there's also the horde of player created content that the game allows access to, and that could provide a lot more gameplay than the original campaign allows for, therefore not necessarily making the Dragonfall expansion worth it, but I recommend it none-the-less.
Awesome game with great potential, best exibhited in the DLC.
Good game. Enjoying the DLC (DragonFall) more than the OC.
Great game. I hardily endorse this product or service.

It's a steal for 3 bucks and change as part of the current 2014 Summer Sale. Get this, if you loved the old Bioware top-down CRPGs, or squad-based RPG's in general. The Steam Workshop is always cranking out new stories!

A pretty good game and a blast from the past in terms of style. Its got an interesting world and characters. The main campaign feels very much like the one from Neverwinter Nights - a holdover until the community builds content via the editor.

The AI is a little weak; the game relies on overwhelming you with bad guys which is a bit annoying but overall combat is really interesting. It's sort of a cross between Advance Wars on the Gameboy and the freeware game Battle of Wesnoth.

Improvements for the future could be a party system that allows you to customise a team of 4. That would be a great addition.
Almost Arcanum, in cyberpunk world.

So Shadowrun Returns. A blast from the past. It's a fantasy/sci-fi turnbased role-playing game set in the shadowrun universe. It's similair to many of the other rpg classics. So what do you  get in the game? Character building, Many choices that don't impact the story but the gameplay, silent charcters (To roleplay better?), A catchy background music and lore that don't make sense if you are not well wersed. (Tho they are as a sidenote in the game and not relevent for the game itself) This is a kickstarted game based on nostalgia and i (Who did not kickstared it and havent even heard of shadowrun before) got hooked. Add to that it's expanding mod community this game is a most have for any lover of classic rpgs
Kvalitni cyberpunk RPG s izometrickym pohledem
Overall nice atmosphere, and great plot
Fantastic world and writing with challenging combat. Just oozes atmosphere. While a little linear and small in scope definitely worth the price of admission.
Pretty good game.  Does a good job of recreating the Shadowrun world.  The combat is very similar to XCOM:EU.  I really wish that the main campaign had voice work instead of just text, though.

Thanks to XCOM: Enemy Unknown I was willing to give Isometric RPG's another shot. I've been enjoying this game a lot in short doses, I'm kind of using it as a primer for when Wasteland 2 is officially released. But it's a solid kickstarter game that I've heard has improvements made on it Dragonfall. If you like descriptive walls of text, neon, cyberpunk, turnbased combat, and deeper RPG elements than some games released nowadays this is a no brainer, especially at it's frequently low prices on an already budget selling point.\n\n8/10
very fun RPG game that plays like a futuristic DnD. funny story as well.
Main campaign is pretty cool, but Dragonfall is best rpg I played in a while
only thing that could make this better is a multiplayer ohh wait they are making one :)
Huge Shadowrun fan.. Welcome back to the Sprawl!

Simple; straightforward gameplay. Turn based (so you can leave it for a minute if you wish). Challenging enough that you have to pay attention (and can fail) - but by no means impossible.\n\nWorkshop provides oodles of extra content. WELL worth it at the 'steam cut prices' usually avilable

The only thing that I really didn't like about this game was that it ended.  The campaign wasn't as long as I would have liked.  That being said it wasn't really THAT short I just played the game a ton.  I got really immersed and wanted to just talk to all the NPCs and explore a bit.  I was a big fan of the shadowrun game for the SNES and love that there was a pretty significant callback to that game in this one.  It really levereged my nostalgia with a brand new experience.  I just started playing the new campaign that was released, Dragonfall and it seems that the same, if not more, care was spent on the development of it as was the original.\n\nI just wish it didn't always have to end.

Game is a great throwback to the old shadowrun games.\nThe creators leave it so people can make mods and adventures for the game, keeping it alive for those who finished the campaigns.\nWell worth the price as you will get many hours of fun gameplay out of it.
Great game feels as close as you can get to the pen and paper game
I like it but... it dosen't really involve you in the game.

Hoy Chummers.

Shadowrun Returns takes you through a solid introduction to the cyberpunk world of shadowrun where classic fantasy, (sword and sorcery) meets cyber enhanced super soldiers.  When I first saw that this game was going to be done I was afraid another company was going to screw it up the way Microsoft did when they failed making another game trying to use the Shadowrun name.    Thankfully this is not the case.  The first story deadman switch is a good solid introduction to the world of being a gun for hire.  While the story is largly liniar the additional content added by players adds vast replayability to the original quest and provides a huge amount of additional content. Dragonfall adds several more hours and more options for play as well.

Another thing that has been nice is that many of the bugs that are/were in this have been fixed.  So many products are released to die where this game has been continually updated to ensure problems when found are solved.
For RPG fans or those who remember playing one of the many table top cyberpunk games,  this is a great game worth every penny.

It's not particularly elegant, nor is it going to bring in any fans who aren't already down with Shadowrun...but damn if this isn't what all of us fans have been waiting for.  An honest, interesting, and close look at the Shadowrun universe and the tools to tell our own stories and make our own content.  Amazing work from Harebrained.  For the price, I can't see why you wouldn't at least try it.

reviewText:
The game is not perfect. There are some real problems with it, but, despite that, I'd still recommend it to anyone who's thinking of giving it a chance.

Gameplay is linear and there are some inherent flaws in the design, for instance the tendency of attacks to roll Missed despite your actual stats. If I did a count, I'm fairly sure the number of times the characters missed surpass the times they actually land a hit. It got ridiculous to the point that I'd get misses 3 times in a row at point blank range. This makes for very frustrating play especially at the endgame portion. There's also an impression of unbalanced design considering that certain builds came off more useful than others. Party members builds seem to have no impact either outside of battles and a certain plot mission. I could have a decker in my party but not be able to do any side decking other than what was neccesary to move the game forward, it made party build up rather pointless and lackluster.

On the upside, it's rather well-written and the characters in-game are rather engaging and interesting. I'm not too familiar with the Shadowrun tabletop but I am a fan of the setting. You can see much effort has gone into the game and the end result is rather polished. The game is, overall, a good effort from an indie developer and while not great, is a decent experience and has lots of potential for the future.

If Dragon Age and Deus Ex had a top down baby, it would be Shadowrun Returns.

The concept, setting, story and music are great (though a few hours hours in you'll get annoyed with the repeated battle music), but the UI and controls are clunky, and the gameplay repetitive. Were it not for the story I would have given it up long ago.

There are also some bugs, such as not being able to select a character to move during the battle. Alt + F4 and reload is the only solution I know of.

Still worth a play through.

The game is good. Somewhat simplistic, with way too much combat and completely linear...

BUT. For a short indie game it does one thing good. Or superbly, actually.

It tells a good story, with well-developed and likable characters. Even gives you something to think about.
That alone makes it a good RPG experience.

Even if it comes with way too much pew-boom-splat :)
This game turned out to be much better than I expected.  A solid rpg system, with good art, and a decent story.  The setting was more interesting than I expected as well.

reviewText:
A diamond in the rough.

Some people have problems with the engine and it's true, it is far from perfect. The Checkpoint system bugged many, and I thought it would get on my nerves when I first read of it but in the end it didnt bother me at all.
The game has a variety of bugs but after I beat it last week they've already patched many of them.

The music was made by the guy that made the music for the SNES game aswell as the guy that made the music for the Genesis/Megadrive game set in the Shadowrun world so they know their stuff.
The graphics are Both beautiful but in terms of animations on the characters, sort of stiff.
So the battles tend to look abit worse than when youre just walking around the world in awe of the neon glory that is the Shadowrun world.

The battle system is very close to the one in the 2012 Xcom remake so all is good there.
Where the game really shines is it's storytelling and characters. The writers did a damn good job and created a world that really pulled me in. I'm usually not one to play games just for its story, but if you are then this is a great one.

The game is definately flawed but hopefully those flaws are worked out over time, and even if they aint, none of them ever really took me out of the experience. I'll be eagerly awaiting the expansions and I'm sure I'll be trying out some mods aswell.

recommended: with plenty of side missions and free time to discover a bit more about the Shadowrun universe

reviewText:
Shadowrun Returns original campaign:
This is a very nice Shadowrun based game, with a good story and gameplay. However, it is a short game and as soon as you learn how to optimize the character skills (and the enemies AI failures...) it is an easy game, even in the very hard mode. Also, it is an extremely linear game, not giving you any options besides the main track of the story. Still, it is a great game and I strongly recommend it to shadowrun lovers, such as myself.

Shadowrun Returns: Dragonfall:
This expansion package brings a very interesting and amusing story line. Definetively worth playing if you liked Shadowrun Returns original campaign. Note that it is not a continuation of the original campaing - you cannot bring your old character into this new campaign - altough some small references can be seem during the game. It is worth mentioning that this campaign is a little longer than Shadowrun Returns original campaign, but still a very linear game. Moreover, the dificulty level is
higher than in the original campaign.
I have been a fan of the Shadowrun series since the original SNES version came out. This game actually was a great successor to the series.

This game is fantastic, surpassed every expectation.  It really captures the feel of the old tabletop game.  The combat is fresh and keeps moving, a concern I had going into it.  Most of all the story, writing, and characterization are top notch.
Although very linear, an engrossing storyline, exceptional soundtrack, and outstanding mod support make this a very worthwhile title.
Worth every single penny! And the second campain Dragonfall is awesome from start to finish!
Fun turn based RPG. Highly recommend.

Sometimes you feel like shooting a guy in the face. Other times you feel like amplifying your fists with magic power and pummeling an enemy to death. Oh look, I'm hacking your system and fighting inside the Matrix.\n\nWhy am I in love wth a troll? Damn. Dragonfall expansion really shines in the narrative. Highly addictive learning about your fellow group of misfits.

I'd say I'm only about halfway through this game so far, but I am loving every minute of it! The visuals and art-style look very nice and I love the cyberpunk themed setting. Combat mechanics are very simplistic and work similar to xcom games, but its rpg elements are very in-depth and enough to compensate for its simplistic combat gameplay.\n\nThe highlight of this game for me is its story-telling. If you don't mind reading (there are no voice actors) and enjoy a good sci-fi conspiracy story (think deus ex) you will enjoy this!

TL;DR Not at all like Shadowrun on 360, great text-based story, must get

I played the Shadowrun deathmatch spinoff for Xbox 360 years ago and it has always had a special place in my heart.  The combat was refreshing and very fun.  It had fleeting little story but I was intrigued by it nonetheless.

It's funny how much of a 180 this game is compared to the spinoff.

The combat is an ersatz XCOM and not really satisfying.  I played on normal so of course I wasn't playing the game to its full potential.  The combat was pretty boring and felt like an afterthought.

BUT WAIT!  This game doesn't suck!  In huge contrast to the only other Shadowrun game I have played this game has a story!  And what a story it is.  The plot is positively enthralling (hehe).  Sorry you'll get it when you buy this magnificent game.    The plot is split into two acts, of which the first I believe is stronger.  The first act is a pretty standard whodunit and the second is... I don't know if I missed out on some backstory from the tabletop game, but it's a lot to take in.  But sometimes it's nice to be overwhelmed by a story, you know?  The characters, dialogue and text descriptions (setting, items, etc.) is really where the game shines.  The characters are interesting (I found myself talking to every single one at every opportunity) and feel real.  Their personalities don't feel fake and nobody does a complete character change halfway through as an excuse for a plot twist which is common in games.  The dialogue is witty and enjoyable.  Sadly there are no voice actors, but it doesn't take away too much from the immersion.

There's just something special about the written word and its power to completely immerse you in a story.  The writers for this game are truly skilled, as the settings described are so much more than what I could ever gain from just seeing it.  There's such a huge emphasis on graphics these days that I think people get caught up in it and forget that sight is only one of many senses.  The written word describes all of them.  Sight, smell, sound, touch, you name it and it can be described.  I hope this game succeeds and more developers join this niche of text-based RPG, as there is truly no better way to immerse the player than to write down what you want them to know.

I give this game a 7/10 but it is really a must buy for me.  The story itself makes the game well worth the price when it's on sale.

If you're looking for a gritty turn-based strategy game in a similar vein to that of XCOM or Omerta, then this is your game. It's set in a dystopian future, the game merges fantasy races into a human world with a cyberpunk setting. The plot has you constantly moving from action to action in what starts out as a simple detective story, but quickly changes gear into a much deeper, darker plot.\n\nThe game is fun. I recommend it and rate it 8/10.
Was a backer and wasn't disappointed, but I could see how some would be.  Kind of linear, but captured some of the feel.  Bought the DLC, MUCH better.  Would reccommend.
good ol' 2D rpg

Great start to a modern era Shadowrun game.  Definitely captures the feel of the pen and paper game while holding on to traditional video game RPG ideas.  Can't wait to try out the editor and play the next campaign!

The story, definitely. Plenty of twists and turns. I daily kept coming back to play the game. I was saddened that I finished it in 13 hrs+ but I'm definitely getting dragonfall? the expansion. And then there's a Steam Workshop for this game! The guns for this turn based rpg do so make a satisfying boom, at least for me. I was also really pleased that I could customize my character the way I wanted. I started as a non magical street samurai but I got enough points over the course of the game to specialize in another skillset as well. You can go into spellcasting, summoning, cyberdecking or drone rigging. If it isn't obvious by now, I like this game.

Loved the original as a kid. Wasn't overly impressed when I first purchased this, but the graphical updates have created a better environment for a more immersive experience. Wished voice acting didn't cost and arm and a leg...adding a little bit of this would make this game great. BUT, the combat is solid, writing is good, and community is strong (for user mods). I would recommend this game on sale. Make sure to grab the dlc to this game. It's brings new elements to a campaign that are a must IMHO.

For an old time Shadowrun fan this game feels like going back to a good old friend.

On top of all, the Dragonfall expansion improves over several small details in the original, giving you more freedom to choose your path or make small or larger choices.

I'd recommend it to any Shadowrun fan out there :)

dont ♥♥♥♥ing buy the deluxe package. its a rip off they make it seem that the Dead man's switch is extra content. But infact is the first game. You are paying a ♥♥♥♥ ton more for only the anthology and sountrack

I actually never played any Shadowrun games before this, but it reminded me of many other games I loved and played all the time when growing up. After playing through Deadman's Switch I have to say this game is absolutely fantastic!
Where do I begin? The art and the detail in each area and character is very nice, the rules are sleek and easy to learn (though at first I was a bit intimidated coming into a ruleset I had no prior experience with).  The combat system flows great, it really keeps your interest. The writing is amazing, it feels like I am reading a good novel at times. On top of it all the music is sleek and fitting to the cyberpunk setting.

I do have a few complaints, I did find some bugs, while not game breaking, they were an annoyance for a bit. And while the character development is solid for most of the characters that are a part of the story, I really wish I could interact more with the runners I hire, a one sentence description of the character does not do them justice.

Because of this game I am looking into playing the Pen and Paper Shadowrun as well. Overall I would highly recommend this game to anyone that enjoyed games such as Baldur's Gate, Neverwinter Nights (if you love user made campaigns).
Great game that takes me back to the early 90's. Classic point and click gameplay with a decent story. I definitely recommend this game to anyone.

This is a game that could have been so much more. I love the setting and I think that for the most part they did a great job creating the world. However while it looks great it often feels like a set rather than a living city. Every place you go plays out more or less the same. Click the 2 or 3 people with talk symbols over their head, look for the 1 or 2 items that you can click on the map somewhere, fight a few guys, leave area. I like the world, I want to be able to go around and explore it and have a reason to do so. Even if it is just flavor text like You see a grimy computer terminal
date:
you can tell it has been well used" for example. I want to be able to go around and look at everything and just explore.

The world graphics are great for the most part. There are a few things that really take me out of it like the quick loop of papers blowing in the wind over and over. The birds that fly off when you walk by are great though. My biggest gripe with the graphics is that the characters rarely look anything like their super awesome avatar pictures. I see a big orc character and when I walk up to him his avatar picture is of a skinny orc. The avatar picture I made for my guy is very thin but his character model is chunky with a way different head. Just pulls me out of the story.

I like the story and I like the characters. It was well written and kept me interested. Even the loading screen text telling me about the place I was heading was great. I do wish that there was less travel here travel there though. I just get interested in an area and nope off to the next place. Maybe if rather than quick traveling everywhere there were inbetween areas with optional side stuff to do then all the traveling around would feel more cohesive.

I have not played the official DLC mission yet so maybe they fixed some of my problems with it. Despite the problems

Well, where do I begin? I'll start by saying the developers really did the Shadowrun name a lot of justice with this release. Basically a party-based tactical RPG set in the cyberpunk world of Shadowrun. It really nails that futuristic, dystopian vibe I look for in this type of story. The gameplay is very enjoyable and you'll have a lot of fun leveling up your character in the main campaign. The options for character development and customization are pretty solid.

My only complaint is - the main campaign is too short. Sure, you can get Dragonfall (the expansion) for another $15, and that is much bigger than the original campaign... but the stock capaign just sort of disappointed me.
