reviewText: Shadowrun Returns is a surprisingly addictive isometric cyberpunk RPG. The combat has enough tactical depth to keep you on your toes, but the real strength to this game is the story. The dialogue between characters is both interesting and meaningful, often making use of slang specific to the Shadowrun universe which aids immersion. The game does feel quite linear at times and conversational options are often inconsequential, but it doesn't detract from the experience thanks to engaging storyline. I'm genuinely surprised at the quality of the game, especially when consideration is given to the asking price. I think anyone looking for a modern take on old-school RPG'ing would be wise to try Shadowrun.\n\nNote: ignore the playtime, my shadowrunning was done offline.

I have finished both Shadowrun Returns: Dead Man's Switch and Shadowrun Returns: Dragonfall. What I can say is that I like both campaigns, but Dragonfall is the better out of the two (more cyberware, more options, bigger campaign in my opinion).

After having finished Dragonfall, I can say that Dead Man's Switch was lacking a bit, and I most likely won't play it again. However, I would find myself playing Dragonfall again.

So what I did not like was the lack of cyberware and game options, but the campaign was great. You should definitely play Dead Man's Switch before Dragonfall. I am hoping another DLC will come out soon.

Another thing I did not like was that there were not any Mr. Johnsons, like there were in the Sega Genesis version. That, alongside a taxi system should be implemented in the next DLC (after Dragonfall).

A really entertaining game with quite a bit of user generated content, and only one problem.

The first scenario, Dead Man's Switch is very well written-if a little predictable for those familiar with the genre, but if you want all of the loot, you'll have to put a lot of points in Decking. The Charisma required to haggle makes some sense, but one of the great things about Shadowrun is the crew you work with filling in gaps in each others' skills.

Want to be a Technomage or Rigger-Shaman hybrid? Cool. Want to be able to get all of the loot? Still need to unload a lot of points in Decking because you, not your team, will be the one cracking locks to get to it.

The combat system is adapted fairly well from the tabletop.

Its an old school rpg in the vein of planescape torment, Its still got the elves and trolls but now with a nice dash of cyperpunk.

Dragonfall is the better campaign and worth its price.

It has a editor too if your into that sort of thing, and a workshop.

I was a huge fan of the SNES Shadowrun game.  This new game not only is a worthy follow-up, but a true sequel!  Shadowrun Returns improves on all the shortcomings SNES players had to tolerate, as well as bringing the game into the modern age.  For a budget game especially, everything about this game is well balanced.  The hand-drawn graphics are slick and the lighting is pretty and immersive.  Character development is satisfying and the story is truly interesting and perfect for the world of Shadowrun.\n\nThe only aspects of this game that reveal its price tag are the limited sound effects, character art and voice dialogue.  But let's be honest - how much more often do voice-overs ruin a game?  Besides, the core of the game is true and enjoyable, the limited art is beautiul and detailed, and the action is as polished as the latest X-Com game (which is also a treat.)  Do yourself a favor: if you've never played Shadowrun for the SNES, give this a try.  And if you loved the SNES game as much as I, you will not be disappointed.  Either way, GET THIS GAME!
Awesome.  Having fun with it so far.

It was a good game in it's own right. Normal wasn't very difficult at all,but there is a hard mode. The story line was quite good and it had the general feel of the old game, but I was wanting more of the old game mechanics. There was very little decking in the game, which was one of my favorite parts of the original. Alli in all. I'm glad I bought it and I'm glad I played it. 7/10
Love the graphics and style of this game. I remember playing Shadowrun 2nd Ed and the feel is awesome. Love the interface as well. Very slick, great game.
Shadowrun(story, setting, and enviroment) + Fallout Tactics(controls) = Shadowrun Returns\n\nNuff said, if you don't like those games, chances are you might be turn off by this game.

The new Berlin campain (Dragonfall) is everything the Seattle one (Dead Man's Switch) wished it was. Shadowrun Returns retains the feel of a table-top RPG kind of campain, due to its origins. Dragonfall is a broader and deeper campain compared to Dead Man's Switch, where choices matter more, dialog has more branches, and the world feels bigger. And let's not forget how well Berlin lends itself to cyberpunk !\nIf you're hesitating on getting the game or the Berlin DLC, I say go for it.
Perr good game, the Dragonfall DLC improves it bunches, but it's still good even with just the base game.
I love choose your own adventure !
The Game is Great and the New DLC is awesome Fixed alot of the issue in the main game. :)
If there was added a larger amount of weapons/armor and a kind of 'free play' mode then I would be playing this all the time.
put it in your mouth, swish it around. do you taste that? that's pretty awesome, innit?\n\nthis game is the equivalient of mouth goodness.
Expanding on every single good thing in the first campaign, Dragonfall is worth every. single. <currency> you paid/will pay for it.
a classic turn based shadowrun game, good story fun run, and the builder is worth makeing a run or two of your own. a good reboot to a great RPG.  buy it play it be happy!
Whether you're a fan of the Shadowrun franchise or not, this is a great tactics game. The campaign is a lot of fun and user-generated content is constantly being updated.
A great game, Brings back the old school feeling of rpg's, Reading the book and controlling the outcome. I little words, I LOVE THIS GAME.

The game overall is pretty cool.  But dont expect to follow up with your character from Shadowrun Returns.  Its a whole new chapter and you need to spin a new character as well.

Other than that the story was very enjoyable and had a lot of interesting plot twists.  This is what a modern traditional RPG plays like and I enjoyed it very much.

Going out on a limb here, but if there ever was an MMO of Shadowrun, I think I would play it forever.  Until then, this chapter filled my want for one... now its back to W* =)

I never played the table top or the MMO shooter no one else seems to have played either, but Shadowrun Returns hits all the important bits for a western RPG: flexible charecter progression, a plot that raises the stakes as you progress, comrades of drinking age, and a fun enviroment that doesn't need hundreds of codex entries to explain what the hell all is going on.\n\nIts good tactical fun for a reasonable price: beating the game won't make you sad to leave the charecters, but it will feel like you came from somewhere and did something. If that's not you cup of tea, go find a game where the protagonist has three love intrests he doesn't even notice in between beating up spiders and panther bear robots in his quest to slay god. I'm sure that is much better time spent...

As a fan of good ol Forgoten Realms style RPG's this game is nostalgy for me. Based on great universe of Shadowrun, with well designed system, very nice graphics and amazing story (even in fan made campaings) it's great fun for every evening. If you haven't played it, you should try it right now, chummer!

Get this game if you want to practice your campaign making, whether for video games or DnD-like sessions. I got through both the Core Campaign(Dead Man's Switch) and the Dragonfall campaign, plus a few highly recommended fan-made campaigns, so I could get a feel of what I could do with the Editor. Dragonfall Campaign is REALLY good by the by. This editor is just maddening with the amount of stuff you can put into it. Completely free to write whatever, answers the players can choose from, map, tile, and prop placement. You can get damn creative with it. Whether you want to just run campaigns(Which you can get from Nexusmods or Steam Workshop easily enough), or create them, this Hobbit recommends this game.
It does have heart

A unique and original combination of fantasy and sci-fi, Shadowrun Returns is an RPG with solid turn-based combat system, interesting setting and story, and a complex but easy to learn levelling system, using 'karma' to upgrade certain abilities. Though the game campaign is pretty linear, and there is only one campaign, there are lots of different player-made missions available to get through the workshop. Worth getting if you're into cRPGs and stuff

Great game! I've never reviewed one before, but I think this a real hidden gem. The graphics are lush and immersive, player creation is simple but very detailed. The abilities, classes, and combat are very true to the paper and pencil Shadowrun RPG (which is great). NPC dialog and dialog response options are some of the best I've ever seen in a game. They really went all out with this one, even more impressive because it was made by a realtively small developer (I'm going to look for more games from Harbrained after playing this).
Best feature of all though, great TURN-BASED rpg combat. Reminiscent of some of the best rpgs ever made, but with gorgeous graphics thrown in. I would recommend the Dragonfall scenario too, just because this game is so good, one story isn't enough!
Also, I got the core game on sale for just $5, literally best five dollars I've ever spent!
The dev team really hit it out of the park on this one, I'll be looking for more of your games and any future kickstarters you do, please keep up the amazing work!
Cool game. If you take your time you'll really get absorbed into the world and story (:
Not a horrible take on the SNES Shadowrun game.  The campaign is a bit short but I enjoyted it.
Great engine, very well transmitted atmosphere, The original campaign may lack a bit, but Dragonfall may have the best CRPG plot in the last few years.

Sometimes all you need are 2D isometric graphics! Not the best game ever, but if you enjoy turn-based RPGs, you might enjoy this. You'll probably like it more if you played the Shadowrun paper-based RPG.

If you are a fan of Shadowrun or Cyberpunk and enjoy top down isometric games, you owe it to yourself to check this out.  The writing is well done and oozes the blend of noir, sci-fi, and fantasy that makes up the Shadowrun universe. The game play is very reminiscent of Fallout 2 or XCOM and centered around squad based tactical combat.

Great game, good writing and a good story. I just wish it was all voice-acted, I love good voice-acting in a game, I think it makes it so much better. *Not* an open-world game, linearly story driven but the story is good enough to keep you entertained.

Picked this up on offer this Bank Holiday weekend and have really enjoyed it. I have yet to explore the additional content (which looks really good) so this refers only to the main campaign 'Dead Man's Switch'. I enjoyed the Shadowrun universe, the characters were almost consistently interesting, the dialogue options fun and there was enough variety on offer to warrant two or three play-throughs (well, almost three, more on that later). In fact, this game has inspired me to learn more about Shadowrun - a marketing success, for sure!

Character creation allows for a lot of customisation, either from one of the standard templates or free-form (the latter allows some creative combinations once you've got the hang of the gameplay mechancis). While there is a lot of replayability in character classes (you'll have a different experience as an Adept than as a Decker, for instance) it struck me that my playthrough as a decker (who can hack into the 'Matrix' and fight additional combat scenarios within computer programmes) allowed greater access to content and secrets. A shame as I did feel the game was sort of pushing me to play as a decker, and while this is an interesting and challenging character class, it limits your access to combat and magic specialisations.

My main criticisms are that even a year after release I kept encountering bugs - including a major game-breaking bug that meant I could not finish a level. In short, it simply would not end combat or allow me to initiate dialogue at one point, even when the combat was over and dialogue bubbles were above people's heads. This was a pain and recurred again even after a level restart. Other criticisms were niggling and broke the immersion rather than the game - playing as a troll, for instance, didn't change dialogue options to a playthrough as a human or as an elf - which was a shame (bar one person calling me a racist name) and I'd loved to have used the in-game mechanic of building your own gang to go on more than just main plot missions. A couple of side missions could have helped me diversify my character build, get some better equipment and feel more prepared to take on the end of game boss on the hardest difficulty.

The game itself is focused on a single short story (took me about 8 hours the first time, 5-6 after that) which felt more like an introduction to the universe than a standalone game, which is an odd design decision, but it did mean I finished the game eager for more - rather than with a 'more traditional rpg' like Baldur's Gate where I tend to get fed up well before the finale. While this focus meant a satisfying resolution to the compelling storyline, it also meant there were no side missions, no additional content and limited opportunities for exploration. While additional content looks to rectify this, most involve creating new characters, so those I created for Dead Man's Switch won't be coming with me.

tl;dr - Great, immersive, colourful and engaging game that I'd rate 3.5-4/5. This score would be higher if the game was longer, featured greater variety outside combat, had opportunities for exploration and a few more side missions and didn't have game breaking bugs this long after release!
Great game. Mix Baldurs Gate, X-com and Bladerunner and there is Shadowrun Returns. Awesome!
Reminded me of the first one from all those years ago on the SNES, get it in the sale while you still can, it's great!

Awesome game. Like Fallout 2 except set in a different world, one of techno-mages, futuristic hackers, and cities in the embrace of dark-souled corporations. The script is well-crafted, and the story unfolds in a somewhat liner but enjoyable way. The combat is a genuinely fun, turn based system akin to a D&D system, but with rules based on the Shadowlands tabletop game.

It is worth the $15 dollars charged for it.

I generally don't like indie games, but a few have stood out to me, Bastion is one of them, Brothers Tale of Two Sons, and Shadowrun has definately entered this elite group for me.
I like it so far. Great successor to old sega game.
a damn fine RPG game. I love it.

This game is freaking awesome. A cyberpunk game with the same story telling potential as Dragon Age? Turne-Based combat that isn't a complete drag on the action? An excellent digital rendition of the Shadowrun system? All present and accounted for.\n\nI'm not all the way through Dragonfall yet, but so far, it feels like a full-fledged game in the same sense that Shadowrun Returns is. Imagine that all the time spent making the original engine was instead put into developing the Dragonfall campaign. It's going to be epic.
Much like X-Com but in my opinion way better due to it's RPG elements
Exceptionally fun. It's like playing a tabletop RPG on your computer. Nice visuals, but finicky controls.

Such an amazing game.

The combat was absolutely flawless, the amount of customization is stunning, and ever character is extremely unique.

It's reminiscent of a time when games took thought and effort to complete, and it makes you feel like you earned the rewards.

The only problem in the entire game (to me anyways), is the fact that the levels are pretty linear, the amount of choices makes up for this though.

There's just so much great stuff put into this game that it's hard to write about, 8 hours spent on the basic campaign, and a whole other one left.

Anyone who loves story driven rpgs and the combat of Xcom will fall in love with this game from the start.
